story:
We’re coming back. We need your help.

We’ve been hearing from you. On Facebook and Instagram, through our audience survey, through the email form on our website, you’ve told us you’re excited that Cinema Salem is coming back. We’re excited too.

Many of you have asked if you can help. You can.

We want to raise $75,000 to help Cinema Salem open again as a safe, comfortable and fun place for our audiences. We will set subsequent goals as we learn more from you about what kind of space our community wants. 

Help us become Salem’s hub for arts and culture

For 15 years, Cinema Salem has presented first-run films, hosted multiple film festivals (including Salem Film Fest and Salem Horror Fest), and opened windows into arts and culture through special-event film screenings and a wide array of live programming. Going forward, we want to be even more of a home for the arts, a greater resource for Salem’s creative workforce, and a place that welcomes people from every part of our community.

Phased plans for improvements

Here are our current plans and associated costs:

Phase 1 (in progress, to be completed by Memorial Day): $55,000

  • Lobby and concession area, entrance corridor, restrooms
  • New carpets: $15K.
  • Painting: $15K.
  • Restroom clean-up and repairs: $10K
  • HVAC upgrades and deep cleaning: $15K.

Phase 2: Three theater halls (schedule TBD)

  • New carpet for aisles and on walls: $20,000
  • New seats: $25,000-$40,000 per hall

(Note: We hear you about the seats. A new seat today can cost $300 or more. So before we dive in, we want to learn from the community how best to use our halls. That will help us understand what seats to buy to give the best experience. Needless to say, the success of this campaign can have a big effect on how quickly we can replace seats!)

Projectors (already purchased): $125,000

(Note: The projectors that had been in service were nearing the end of their useful life and came with a leasing arrangement that restricted the kinds of films we could show. We have purchased three new NEC 1201 laser projectors.)

Ambitions down the road:

  • More substantial restroom renovations
  • Expanded bar and lounge area
  • Expanded live performance capacity
  • Renovating the cafe and bringing it back to life
     

Help us make Cinema Salem a place you’ll love more than ever – AND be the first to own exclusive new Cinema Salem merchandise and get special offers.

As a thank-you for contributions, we’re offering T-shirts, tickets, and special Salem packages. In addition, we will acknowledge our larger contributors by name in our lobby and on our screens before film showings. 

Any money raised through this campaign will go toward improvements and upgrades to the space. If we do not meet our fundraising goal, we will still work toward realizing the ambitions we’ve described here. BUT… the more help we get from our friends, the faster we can make Cinema Salem the place we – and you – want it to be. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially. If you aren’t in a position to give, please consider sharing our campaign with your own networks and with people who may want to support the future of Cinema Salem!

Our team and track record

We’ve assembled a team with a wide range of skills and experience, including film, live events, art exhibits, and more:

Jonathan Kieran is joining the team as Cinema Salem’s head of film curation after serving as a programmer at the New Orleans Film Festival, where he helped craft diverse, vibrant slates of films for the city’s adventurous and engaged filmgoers.

John Andrews and the team at Creative Collective have produced hundreds of live shows, events, pop-ups, and initiatives throughout Essex County and work with over 200 small businesses, makers, artisans, performers, and other creators. 

Peter Horne began working at Cinema Salem when it opened in 2006 and moved up the ranks to a manager position, where he oversaw the cinema’s daily operations and facilities.

Elaine Gerdine and Marshall Strauss are the new owners. Between them, they have written libretti for opera, worked with political dissidents in China and the former USSR, and led and supported non-profits and other community organizations for decades. Their interest in Cinema Salem goes beyond keeping the venue alive, to building a permanent arts center for the city.

The final part of our team is YOU. Cinema Salem means nothing without the community we serve. So please share with us: your ideas, your enthusiasm, your dreams – and some money if you can. With your help, we’ll make Cinema Salem a place for all to enjoy and where everyone can feel at home.
story_txt:
We’re coming back. We need your help.We’ve been hearing from you. On Facebook and Instagram, through our audience survey, through the email form on our website, you’ve told us you’re excited that Cinema Salem is coming back. We’re excited too.Many of you have asked if you can help. You can.We want to raise $75,000 to help Cinema Salem open again as a safe, comfortable and fun place for our audiences. We will set subsequent goals as we learn more from you about what kind of space our community wants. Help us become Salem’s hub for arts and cultureFor 15 years, Cinema Salem has presented first-run films, hosted multiple film festivals (including Salem Film Fest and Salem Horror Fest), and opened windows into arts and culture through special-event film screenings and a wide array of live programming. Going forward, we want to be even more of a home for the arts, a greater resource for Salem’s creative workforce, and a place that welcomes people from every part of our community.Phased plans for improvementsHere are our current plans and associated costs:Phase 1 (in progress, to be completed by Memorial Day): $55,000
Lobby and concession area, entrance corridor, restrooms
New carpets: $15K.
Painting: $15K.
Restroom clean-up and repairs: $10K
HVAC upgrades and deep cleaning: $15K.
Phase 2: Three theater halls (schedule TBD)
New carpet for aisles and on walls: $20,000
New seats: $25,000-$40,000 per hall
(Note: We hear you about the seats. A new seat today can cost $300 or more. So before we dive in, we want to learn from the community how best to use our halls. That will help us understand what seats to buy to give the best experience. Needless to say, the success of this campaign can have a big effect on how quickly we can replace seats!)Projectors (already purchased): $125,000(Note: The projectors that had been in service were nearing the end of their useful life and came with a leasing arrangement that restricted the kinds of films we could show. We have purchased three new NEC 1201 laser projectors.)Ambitions down the road:
More substantial restroom renovations
Expanded bar and lounge area
Expanded live performance capacity
Renovating the cafe and bringing it back to life 
Help us make Cinema Salem a place you’ll love more than ever – AND be the first to own exclusive new Cinema Salem merchandise and get special offers.As a thank-you for contributions, we’re offering T-shirts, tickets, and special Salem packages. In addition, we will acknowledge our larger contributors by name in our lobby and on our screens before film showings. Any money raised through this campaign will go toward improvements and upgrades to the space. If we do not meet our fundraising goal, we will still work toward realizing the ambitions we’ve described here. BUT… the more help we get from our friends, the faster we can make Cinema Salem the place we – and you – want it to be. Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that not everyone can contribute financially. If you aren’t in a position to give, please consider sharing our campaign with your own networks and with people who may want to support the future of Cinema Salem!Our team and track recordWe’ve assembled a team with a wide range of skills and experience, including film, live events, art exhibits, and more:Jonathan Kieran is joining the team as Cinema Salem’s head of film curation after serving as a programmer at the New Orleans Film Festival, where he helped craft diverse, vibrant slates of films for the city’s adventurous and engaged filmgoers.John Andrews and the team at Creative Collective have produced hundreds of live shows, events, pop-ups, and initiatives throughout Essex County and work with over 200 small businesses, makers, artisans, performers, and other creators. Peter Horne began working at Cinema Salem when it opened in 2006 and moved up the ranks to a manager position, where he oversaw the cinema’s daily operations and facilities.Elaine Gerdine and Marshall Strauss are the new owners. Between them, they have written libretti for opera, worked with political dissidents in China and the former USSR, and led and supported non-profits and other community organizations for decades. Their interest in Cinema Salem goes beyond keeping the venue alive, to building a permanent arts center for the city.The final part of our team is YOU. Cinema Salem means nothing without the community we serve. So please share with us: your ideas, your enthusiasm, your dreams – and some money if you can. With your help, we’ll make Cinema Salem a place for all to enjoy and where everyone can feel at home.

story:
The Campaign

We are deep in pre-production for a Proof of Concept short film titled, "Within I." The short film will serve as a visual representation of the narrative story to help us promote and include with our treatment for a web-series of the same story and universe of, "Within I." Having gone through so much schooling and learning from experience as any new filmmaker, this project is a passion project with hopes of becoming more than that and representing a protagonist that is underrepresented in mainstream TV and streaming platforms; those who grew up with social and mental struggles as they navigate the world. By supporting us, you are helping many of us on the cast and crew reach a new level in our creative endeavors and our future success. We appreciate any and all your support! Do you want to know more?
 

The Story

A secluded young woman running away from her life’s problems suddenly finds herself with the ability to travel into her subconscious mind. Meeting her subconscious there, the world within her mind reflects the struggles of an introverted life and becoming an adult in the real world. As problems never go away on their own, she learns that something darker is always present and that she may have to learn to take life head on.
 

Director’s Statement

We often need to take a break from life to figure things out in a world of noise but we can never escape it so we try to adapt and find a way to overcome it. This noise can be anything from work, personal, private life struggles and our own health. Growing up, I was the kid that would become friends with everyone and well liked. Until I moved to a new district for high school, I was on my own trying to figure out who I was like most teenagers. As the first generation of my family born in the states, a minority, it was almost impossible to talk to my family about my struggles because the culture and society is different than what they grew up in. Navigating relationships with people, it was apparent that I was mostly alone with no one I could trust to help me navigate my high school years. This project is important to me as it tells the story of a protagonist whose struggles with social anxiety and finding a place for oneself to belong takes her to consult the only person they could talk to, her own subconscious. As she interacts with her subconscious to learn ways to cope with and figure out life, she will learn to grow from each experience to tackle life head on.
 

The Characters of "Within, I"

GABRIELLE - She enjoys reading books and letting her imagination go in drawings. She is introverted with little social skills. Does not have any friends and often just feels lonely but still pushes on in life. A college Freshman at a local community college she lives at home and has not achieved many of what others her age have such as a driving license, having a car, or even making any significant friends or relationships with others. She works at a small library close to home where she learns more about the world than from her own Dad. There is a fear inside her that she can not understand as she reaches for her own independence becoming an adult.

 

SUBCONSCIOUS GABRIELLE - Takes the appearance of Gabrielle but in costume from the books that Gabrielle reads, stories she has heard or drawings she made. Has the same struggles that Gabrielle does and is always on a task to complete, find, or discover something related to Gabrielle’s life.

 

JOHN (DAD) - Over protective of Gabrielle and does not think she is capable on her own. Feels the need to make decisions for her and keep her close. Also does not want her to grow up with fears he will then be alone just like how his wife left them. He is a failing writer and artist always trying to make the next best hit but has a small following if any.

 

THE BEAST - Always has a physical form of either a creature or person that Gabrielle knows from the real world or from the books she reads. It always makes itself present though often it does not make itself appear until there is an imminent need to make a decision on a problem in Gabrielle’s life.

 

THE SUBCONSCIOUS WORLD - This is a place that only makes itself visible to Gabrielle. As she navigates through life, this world takes on a different look and feel. From a safe, calm and comforting place, to then a strange and sometimes dark place; her mind changes as she experiences life and the struggles it comes with.
 

Find Us on Social Media
 

Instagram

Facebook

Webpage

IMDb

 

What Your Support and Contributions Will Do

By sharing and or contributing to our campaigns it will help with the cost of making the film such as:

  • Permits to film at locations
  • Insurance for the Production
  • Crafty and Meals for the Cast and Crew
  • Equipment Rentals
  • Production Design
  • Post Production Editing

 

Crowdfunding Goals

25% goal will cover:

Production Insurance.

50% goal will cover:

Production Insurance, Filming Permits, Crafty and Meals for Cast (2), Crew (20) and Extras (14).

75% goal will cover:

Production Insurance, Filming Permits, Crafty and Meals for Cast (2), Crew (20) and Extras (14), Equipment Rentals.

100% goal will cover:

Production Insurance, Filming Permits, Crafty and Meals for Cast (2), Crew (20) and Extras (14), Equipment Rentals, Production Design and Post Production Editing.


The Impact

These are some of the impacts this successful campaign will make to us, our audience and those who relate to the narrative:

  • Help an Asian American Director achieve his dreams of getting his story out there in the world.
  • Help our crew achieve the level of professionalism to produce quality work to showcase our abilities as most of us are emerging artists in our respectable fields.
  • Tell a story about a protagonist that is less mainstream and relatable to many of those who grow up without support in their lives.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute any money to this campaign, that is okay! If you like this narrative and would like to see us succeed, there are other ways to help:

  • Follow us on Instagram and Facebook at "Within I Film".
  • Comment, Like, Share our posts on social media.
  • Stay up to date on our progress as we update the status of our production.

We appreciate any level of support and hope you will follow us on this wonderful journey!

 

Meet the Production Team

 

Jonny - Writer/ Director/ DP / Executive Producer

Previously a professional sushi chef, I've reconnected with my creative side and pursued my BFA in Media Studies from the University of Southern Maine 2017 and an MFA in Cinema and Media Production at Boston University 2019 concentrating on the Cinematographer's path. Having worked on many forms of creative content from vlog, documentary, commercial and narrative formats, I've found my passion in telling stories as a Director and Cinematographer.

story:
Deadly Dealings Synopsis:
Mary (Roni Jonah) misses her brother Hank (Stephen McGill) and would do anything to have him back in her world. Her life has been full of regret since that fatal night. Haunted by nightly visions she would give anything to make peace with her brother and return back to a ‘normal’ life. Mary’s roommate and best friend Milo (Adam Freeman) offers the chance to speak to her brother again with the assistance of a spirit board, reluctantly she accepts. The Nightmares grow more intense until she strikes a deal with her dreams and wakes up gasping. What sinister entity has been unleashed?



 

Cast & Crew:

From left to Right

Joe Casterline (Bigfoot Exorcist / Cannibal Cop) will star as Wayne Stephens 
Helene Udy (My Bloody Valentine / Dr. Quinn Medicine Woman) will star as Helen Stephens
Roni Jonah (Shark Exorcist, Volumes of Blood) will Star as Mary Stephens
Adam Freeman (Truly Madly, Cannibal Hookers) will star as Milo, also Writer, and Director.
Roman Jossart (Placid Park, The Wicked One, Wicked Ones) as cinematographer



Stephen McGill (Reunion From Hell, FUKT) will star as Hank Stephens. 
Conor McCarthy (Weredeer, Wetworks) Will star as Aisling.
Dixie Gers (Crazy Fat Ethel, Death Care) will star as Twila.
Ronnie George (Bigfoot Exorcist, Cannibal Hookers) will be playing the Chainsaw Demon.
Deryk Wehrley (Zombieland: Double Tap, Wicked Ones) will be doing Special Effects and Make-Up.

The vision
Deadly Dealings deals with multiple themes throughout, We will be using different light effects and cool colors such as  Pinks, Purples, Blues and Greens to create an atmosphere for the film. We want the audience to feel like they are stuck in a dream that has turned into a nightmare. The Deadly Dealings team has put a lot of effort and and hard work into creating an artistic and organic concept for the film. We want to bring a creative view for people to enjoy and to see a different side of horror. By contributing to Deadly Dealings we will plan on giving a unique spin on the Horror genre: Various Supernatural Influences mixed with Vibrant Colors, Blood, & Glitter. Our team has a Unique Vision that we are dying to share with you

The concept comes from the mind of Adam Freeman. He is an independent actor that has starred in films such as the remake of “Cannibal Hookers”,  and “Savage Vengeance”.  Adam also is the lead actor to Brian Dorton’s upcoming film “Truly, Madly” in which he plays Anthony Boggs whose mother is sexually obsessed and controlling over him. Adam also has worked multiple times with Dixie Gers (Ethel, from The remake of Criminally Insane ”Crazy Fat Ethel”) they first costarred together in “Truly, Madly” before they worked together on the short film “Piggy”.  Dixie then directed Adam in the upcoming anthology “FUKT” (Human Toilet segment). Adam has line produced films from casting, location scouting, choreographing scenes, lighting, filming, writing and project managing.

story:
Synopsis

A broken household is in desperate need of a hand - and are given just that. A Monkey's Paw, complete with three wishes. The family must make a choice: take a gamble at fate, or continue to suffer.

What We Need & What You Get

What are we going to do with the funds?

  • Pay Crew- Because we usually have to make movies for little to no money, it would be amazing to pay our film crew a significant amount. They have worked extremely hard in the past.
  • Rent Better Equipment- Our production company already has access to some great equipment but in order to really get the feeling of the film we would like to use different lens and other camera equipment.
  • Great Locations- Houston is a great place to shoot but booking places can be pricey. This campaign will allow us to get the perfect set to work on.
  • You will receive updates as the production continues on. You'll see our progress in real time.
  • Awesome rewards like a poster and T-shirt. Also an awesome screening of the movie, so everyone that worked on it can see the beautiful movie we have created.
  • Even if we don't get the funding we want, we promise to make the best picture we possibly can. It will be amazing.

The Impact

  • In general, we are artist trying to make the best possible art, using lights, camera and acting. We want to make the best possible feature not only for ourselves but over the people watching at home.
  • We want to uplift our crew members as well, to open up possibilities in the future to not only work on indie films but to work on their own films as well.
  • We want to show the people of Houston that film is an important art that needs to be invested into. Film in Houston is very overlooked, and we want to change that.

Risks & Challenges

We are a new company and that comes with learning. Thankfully we have veterans of the film business to rely on. They are more than willing to help us with the budget and the outcome of the film. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation, We appreciate your time. Please consider the following

  • Telling people you know about this campaign. Family members, friends, co-workers, strangers that will listen. Anyone that maybe interested.
  • share this on social media. Use the indiegogo links to share this site and show is to more people on online.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of young filmmakers who are striving to have more representation for the LGBTQ+ community in the film industry. Our short film In Loving Memory is an LGBTQ+ drama set in the late 1960s that follows a writer who lost her spark as she remembers a pivotal moment in her life spent with her late forbidden love.

Our Goal

With In Loving Memory we want to:

  • Depict a healthy, accurate relationship between two women.
  • Bring LGBTQ+ representation to the big screen.
  • Normalize a lesbian relationship without sexualizing it.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to make this project as good as possible! The funding will be used for:

  • Production design, the art of building a new world for a film. Since In Loving Memory is a period piece, this aspect is crucial to the storytelling of our film. 
  • Costumes; We want to have unique, period accurate costumes for our characters!
  • Post production is the stage where all the pieces get put together. With more funding comes more of an opportunity to licence music, special effects and adds that extra touch to the project!

Here's what you get by helping us make In Loving Memory:

  • By choosing one of our different tiers, you receive premium insights into our production.
  • Access to information about how movies are made that normally stay hidden behind the screen.

Risks & Challenges

During times like these, risks and challenges are always involved so we must be prepared for them. Here are a few ways we are preparing to take on these challenges:

  • To keep all our crew and cast safe, we will follow the regional governments regulations and employ COVID Safety Officers on set who will make sure that everything is safe and sound.
  • Regular and extensive sanitization.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are more ways to help than just funding! Here are some examples:

  • Watch our film once it's available!
  • Keep an eye out for films featuring underrepresented persons in the media! 
  • Spread the word! Share the campaign with the sharing buttons at the top of the page!

Thank you!

- In Loving Memory Team

story:
OVERVIEW

Khana Tillman is a writer, filmmaker and recent UCLA grad, and next year she'll be starting the MFA program at USC for Film Production.

WESTWARD, HO! is a short film she and some dear friends and collaborators are putting together to shoot this June, before Khana heads off to grad school. The project is a true labor of love; it is being developed by a group of young filmmakers, many of whom are alumni from UCLA’s School of Theater Film and Television, and all of whom share a passion for making movies for themselves, by themselves. 

DIRECTOR'S NOTE

WESTWARD HO! is a character-driven surreal tragicomedy, largely inspired by such films as 20th Century Women, Y Tu Mama Tambien, and Ingrid Goes West. Throughout my life I have always been fascinated by the dynamics of friend groups and the toxicity we often endure for the sake of companionship. This is what WESTWARD, HO! mainly explores. 

Through this short, I am also seeking a type of truth, which comes from an honest representation of these addicting, but fraught relationships. Where do they stand in our grand personal histories? And at what point does one decide a friendship hurts more than it heals?

I want to be part of a new era of independent filmmaking that prioritizes collaboration, inclusivity, and pushing the needle forward, not just on screen but also off. Although I am still in the early stages of my career, I am determined to foster that environment now. I am elated to say that our cast and crew reflects that ethos, being a majority of female and non-binary artists.

The only large, fortified wall preventing us from actualizing this dream are those pesky dollars. Which is why I am here today, in that classic NPR fundraising drive way, to ask if you would contribute to our funding and help bring this film to life. 

-Khana Tillman

STORY PREMISE

Poppy, a semi successful influencer, reunites with college friends in the desert to scatter her cat’s ashes. As the night unfolds, suppressed memories resurface and the group is forced to confront a troubling betrayal from their collective past.

CAST

story:
Short Summary

Hey, my name is Jeremy Cascamisi, I am a film student living in NYC trying to bring a character that means the world to me, to life.

I was brought aboard on a Spider-Man project a year and a half ago, it was just me in NYC back then. With time, the script has been changed and Covid- 19 put the project on hold but, with this time, I have made the connections to see the vision through. Spider-Man means the world to me and it is with great honor I wish to bring this character to life.

The funds given will go towards shooting locations and renting out film equipment for the project. As well as provide us with the ability to accomplish the look and atmosphere for the film as well as sell the 1967 time period we want to bring to the table.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Looking for about $2,000 dollars to secure locations, shoot dates and surprise appearances.
  • If you donate your name will be added to the credits of the film.
  • All funds will be put towards this film and its production.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and share the campaign! Thank You!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Please Donate

Hello Everyone,

Please donate to our upcoming short horror film 'Wrath'. We are so excited to bring another one of Rory Tasker's scripts to the screen, but we need your support in order to make it possible. No matter how big or small, we ask that you take 2 minutes to help us. 

Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the Wrath team is still working very hard to make the film happen. In a time like this, filmmaking and many of the other arts, are found to be at risk and in need of additional support; and we need you . 

The Synopsis

'Years after leaving an accomplice to a vicious demise, an Exterminator accepts a job from an unpleasant old man. In doing so, he unwittingly is confronted with his guilty past in the form of a sadistic and incomprehensible horror.'

Wrath is a period piece, and will time travel its audience to the year of 1605, where life as we know it was completely different. 

What will your donations go towards?

Your donations will aid us with location hire, set building, props, hair and make-up, camera equipment, lighting equipment, sound, editing, and much much more. 

Social Media

If you wish to follow along with the journey, and behind the scenes of the film, you can follow our Instagram account; and If you have any questions or comments, don't hesitate to message myself or the Instagram page itself. 

Instagram: @wrathshortfilm

story:
“College bros Percy and Spencer move into a new apartment together. Every apartment needs a good microwave. When they purchase one from a peculiar woman, they discover their new appliance is actually a doorway to the underworld...”

Hey everyone! Our names are Rielly Alexander and Leon Sheen, and we are the producers of Microwave Coven! The current global climate has caused Hollywood to slow down over the past several months, so we wanted to keep our careers active by creating our own content. Rielly came up with the story and the script was written by both him and screenwriter Jordan Campbell. The inspiration for this project came from stoner comedies and 1980s horror films. We want to pay an homage to these genres by incorporating them into this short film. With a talented creative team on board, we believe we can make this project a reality.

You can also help make this a reality!  We greatly appreciate your support.

Check out our intro video below to hear it come from us!

 

 

We got a spicy pizza that we're about to put in the oven. And the delivery is on us. Every dollar we get will go directly to the ingredients below. It's that simple. We might even say it's easy as pie. Heh.

But seriously though, films are expensive to make. So we need YOUR help to get this baby going. And if you are able to support us, we got some perks for ya! Below you'll see a breakdown of how we're gonna divvy up our funds.

 

 

     

    Rielly Alexander

    Producer/Lead Actor

    A native Oregonian, Rielly started acting in theater from a young age and knew it was the career for him. He performed in plays throughout his childhood and teenage years and started acting professionally at 19 years old. He has always had a passion for movies and TV and, for the past few years, has pursued an acting career in front of the camera. He has always been a storyteller at heart and aspires to be a writer and director as well as an actor. He is excited to produce his first short film and hopes it will be the first of many projects in the future!

     

    Leon Sheen

    Producer/Lead Actor

    "Friendly but deadly." An actor from the beautiful city of Honolulu, Hawaii, Leon was inspired to pursue the entertainment industry by his father, a former Hong Kong actor and stuntman. He began his career through short films and YouTube comedy skits, eventually working second team on several major network shows and acting on a multitude of indie films. Leon's vigor as a performer stems from his constant hunger for delicious treats (he's a self-proclaimed foodie) as well as his love for Chinese martial arts, Judo, boxing, and stunts. He hopes to bring a lighthearted but professional energy into this production!

     

    Josh Almario

    Director

    A self-taught filmmaker from Honolulu, Hawaii with an eclectic background of work spanning from short films that have screened at film festivals across the U.S. to multi-million viewed music video work for both indie artists and Atlantic records to high-end fashion campaign work for a variety of beauty brands. He’s no stranger to comedy thanks to his early beginnings creating a plethora of improv YouTube skits and his natural curiosity for experimenting with different styles and genres has made him quite the creative chameleon.

    Josh's previous work can be seen at www.joshalmario.com

     

    Justin Moore

    Cinematographer

    Justin is a cinematographer born and raised in Southern California. He spent many years studying still photography before making the transition into motion pictures. He aspires to use his knowledge to help tell interesting and emotionally engaging stories.

    Justin's previous work can be seen at www.justinmooredp.com

     

    Jordan Campbell

    Co-writer

    Jordan Campbell graduated from Indiana University-Purdue University of Indianapolis with a degree in Film Studies, where he studied acting, horror films, and screenwriting. Jordan currently resides in Los Angeles where he writes horror comedy short films, feature scripts, and television pilots of all genres. You can find Jordan at any given Starbucks in LA typing madly away at what he believes to be the script that will m̶a̶k̶e̶ ̶h̶i̶m̶ ̶f̶i̶l̶t̶h̶y̶ ̶s̶t̶i̶n̶k̶i̶n̶ ̶r̶i̶c̶h̶ touch the imaginations of people for years to come.

     

    Justin Jehle

    Production Manager

    Born in the dregs of coastal Southern California, Justin Jehle broke through the loam of poverty by sheer tenacity off his dream to manage warehouses...I mean to eventually meet his destiny, to be a filmmaker. His neck now tired from the multitude of hats he must wear as a young coordinator/PM/locations/Producer must. He has been told many a time to stop working so hard and that his art is awesome if he were only a middle schooler. A lover and a fighter for love.

     

    Jonathan Munoz

    Visual Effects Supervisor

    A storyteller by heart and a VFX artist by trade, Jonathan Munoz is always finding himself either behind a lens of a camera or behind a computer screen. He has searched far and wide throughout Southern California for the ultimate collaboration in independent short filmmaking. This long trek has finally landed Jonathan in the middle of a talented ensemble dedicated to bringing this wild stoner comedy to life.

    Jonathan's previous work can be seen @JonathanZonum on YouTube

     

    Oh, you’re poor too?

    If you can't support us financially, we totally get it. But we would love it if you could help us by sharing this page on social media! Share it with your bros. Share it with your fam. Share it with the squad. Thanks for being awesome.

Production Manager

Visual Effects Supervisor

A storyteller by heart and a VFX artist by trade, Jonathan Munoz is always finding himself either behind a lens of a camera or behind a computer screen. He has searched far and wide throughout Southern California for the ultimate collaboration in independent short filmmaking. Oh, you’re poor too?
If you can't support us financially, we totally get it. But we would love it if you could help us by sharing this page on social media! Share it with your bros. Share it with your fam. Share it with the squad. Thanks for being awesome.

story:
What is 'HELP'?

'HELP' is the debut feature film from multi award winning filmmaker Blake Ridder.

A painful breakup prompts Grace to visit her friend Liv who is living in the idyllic English countryside with her boyfriend Edward and his dog Polly. The trio start the weekend in high spirits but dark revelations soon cascade the short lived happiness into chaos.

'HELP' is a psychological thriller that has been shot in its entirety on a single location in Somerset England. That's right... WE DID IT! Our new found backers from our previously successful Indiegogo campaigns helped us cover all the costs of pre production and filming. As you can see from our official trailer we were able to bring together a talented team who captured a high quality drama.  We want to go one step further and deliver a memorable film to our backers and fans. We have launched this 'FINAL PUSH' campaign to allow us to bring on board a Composer, Sound Designer a VFX artist and cover festival entries.
 

Why are we making this film & the impact  

First and foremost we fundamentally believe in the power of good storytelling , unique characters and stunning visuals. We want you to be a member of  the 'Help Family' so together we will get viewers talking long after the credits roll. We know we can make this impactful because we are making films we want to see. 'HELP' will have a worldwide distribution in 2021 so like minded movie lovers can get a taste for what is to come from Ridder Films in the future.


 

Meet the director



Blake Ridder is an award-winning director, writer and actor. He is best known for writing, directing and starring in the multi award-winning drama short film The English Teacher (2 x best film awards, 5 x nominations) . An experimental sci-fi C600 (1 semi-finalist, 2 x nominations) with beautiful cinematography, and more recently, the suspenseful thriller A Simple Robbery which this feature film is loosely based on. Blake has also written and directed two fan films on his YouTube channel gaining over 3 millions views in total. 


Meet the cast

Emily Redpath as Grace
Emily is an actor/ performance artist who trains with teacher John Osborn Huges. She has performed on stage in venues such as The Camden People's Theatre and as a voice actor with Big Finish Productions. We are very excited to have Emily playing the lead role in HELP.

Sarah Alexandra Marks as Liv.
Sarah executed an impressive role in A Simple Robbery, we're very happy and lucky enough to get her back in HELP playing as Liv. Sarah is an actress/writer who trains with Gary Condes, acting coach. She has performed in both stage and film, including The Royal Opera House. She recently worked on a TV Pilot, Autumn Tree that will hopefully be coming to your screens soon. 



Louis James as Edward.
Louis is an actor/producer who trained at Drama Centre London. He has performed on both stage and screen racking up impressive credits, reviews, nominations and awards. Winning two best actor awards in The English Teacher.

Behind the scenes 



Why we need your HELP

With your contributions, you will be making the following post-production impact on this film:

  • Editing
  • Sound design
  • Music composer
  • Colourist
  • Marketing 
  • Festival entry fees
  • Distributions

What do you get in return

With your generous contributions, we want to also give you something back more than just a well done film. Here are some of the perks we are offering:

  • A digital copy of the film and signed poster 
  • Private chat with cast and crew
  • Private chat with cast and crew 
  • Exclusive access to behind the scenes footage 

You can also HELP by sharing this campaign with your friends and family. We seriously cannot wait to shoot this epic thriller of a film. Thank you. 
 

Follow HELP on social media

Twitter: @HELPthemovie
Instagram: @HELP.Movie
Facebook: HELP The Movie

story:
I’ve tried to write about my relationship with my dad several times over the last few years.

Each story has morphed into something else. I was too close to the subject material emotionally to tell a story that could resonate as I intended, too young to understand the toll my father’s actions had taken on me, and too bitter to be objective. I’m ready to tell the story of alcoholism’s toxicity to children of addicts now.  The film I will make is about a recovering alcoholic father and his daughter trying to connect but having little common ground on which to stand. 

I haven’t talked to my dad in some time as a way of protecting myself, but often wonder what our relationship would look like if he were sober.  In examining the complexities of addiction and family dynamics, I want to reach others dealing with similar situations as well as those experiencing other family dysfunction with similar harm done. I want to address the reality that recovery is not linear,  neither or the alcoholic nor for their family.

Alcoholism is a disease, often treated as a choice in society and in film.

The dynamic between an alcoholic and their child is complex, and different in every situation. The disconnect that children of alcoholics can feel with addict parents and their ability to disassociate in moments of emotional discomfort creates another layer to the performance of the actors in my script. As a director, I plan to examine these dynamics with the actors while helping them create a superficial familiarity, we can then play the complex dynamic on several emotional levels.

What We Need 

Making a film is expensive. There are a lot of hidden costs and hoops to jump through. This is where you come in. All of the funds raised will go directly to production and post production for this film. 

  • My fundraising goal is hefty. Most of the funds will go towards physical production: paying cast and crew, renting locations, feeding my cast and crew, renting equipment, permits and insurance. The rest will go towards post production: editing, sound, festival entries, marketing.
  • In the event we do not reach our entire goal, I will cut where I can. I did go to film school after all. I'm used to working on shoe string budgets and playing multiple roles. 

 

Risks & Challenges

It is both an ethical and moral challenge to deal fairly with the subject matter of addiction and recovery. Alcoholism  should be presented as any other disease would be; with an unbiased, objective view. I will balance the nuances of the issue. The character who is the recovering alcoholic is dealing with his own demons; his daughter is dealing with the trauma that often manifests in those close to addicts. Neither character is right or wrong. Neither is flawless or irredeemable. Both characters’ feelings are valid. I hope to show this dynamic in a restorative way, without exploiting or romanticizing drinking or drunk behavior. I want the film to express that while recovery may be painful, ugly, and messy for everyone involved, it is possible. I want to be authentic and to be fair.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand we're all in a financially uncertain time. If you can't contribute, there are other ways for you to be a part of this process. 


  • Follow us on Instagram. Like us on Facebook.
  • Share my project on your own social media platforms.

Visit our website.

Thank you for your continued support and love. 

Leah
story_txt:
I’ve tried to write about my relationship with my dad several times over the last few years.
Each story has morphed into something else. I was too close to the subject material emotionally to tell a story that could resonate as I intended, too young to understand the toll my father’s actions had taken on me, and too bitter to be objective. I’m ready to tell the story of alcoholism’s toxicity to children of addicts now.  The film I will make is about a recovering alcoholic father and his daughter trying to connect but having little common ground on which to stand. 
I haven’t talked to my dad in some time as a way of protecting myself, but often wonder what our relationship would look like if he were sober.  In examining the complexities of addiction and family dynamics, I want to reach others dealing with similar situations as well as those experiencing other family dysfunction with similar harm done. I want to address the reality that recovery is not linear,  neither or the alcoholic nor for their family.

Alcoholism is a disease, often treated as a choice in society and in film.
The dynamic between an alcoholic and their child is complex, and different in every situation. The disconnect that children of alcoholics can feel with addict parents and their ability to disassociate in moments of emotional discomfort creates another layer to the performance of the actors in my script. As a director, I plan to examine these dynamics with the actors while helping them create a superficial familiarity, we can then play the complex dynamic on several emotional levels.

What We Need 
Making a film is expensive. There are a lot of hidden costs and hoops to jump through. This is where you come in. All of the funds raised will go directly to production and post production for this film. 

My fundraising goal is hefty. Most of the funds will go towards physical production: paying cast and crew, renting locations, feeding my cast and crew, renting equipment, permits and insurance. The rest will go towards post production: editing, sound, festival entries, marketing.
In the event we do not reach our entire goal, I will cut where I can. I did go to film school after all. I'm used to working on shoe string budgets and playing multiple roles. 


 

Risks & Challenges
It is both an ethical and moral challenge to deal fairly with the subject matter of addiction and recovery. Alcoholism  should be presented as any other disease would be; with an unbiased, objective view. I will balance the nuances of the issue. The character who is the recovering alcoholic is dealing with his own demons; his daughter is dealing with the trauma that often manifests in those close to addicts. Neither character is right or wrong. Neither is flawless or irredeemable. Both characters’ feelings are valid. I hope to show this dynamic in a restorative way, without exploiting or romanticizing drinking or drunk behavior. I want the film to express that while recovery may be painful, ugly, and messy for everyone involved, it is possible. I want to be authentic and to be fair.

Other Ways You Can Help
I understand we're all in a financially uncertain time. If you can't contribute, there are other ways for you to be a part of this process. 

Follow us on Instagram. Like us on Facebook.


Share my project on your own social media platforms.
Visit our website.
Thank you for your continued support and love. Leah

story:
Moodboard

 

 

Meet The Team

Director:

Akua Abedi-Boafo is the CEO, founder of the UK based production company, AAB Productions. Akua is a hard-working creative, striving to make and leave her mark in the creative industry. She is currently studying English Literature and Drama in her last year of university in London. She started out as an actress, working on various web series, adverts and high profile movie sets in the UK such as Kid Who Would Be King, Love and Hip Hop Hollywood, Mission Impossible and many more.

She started writing blogs in 2017 under the name of Kwiyah Writes (@kwiyahwrites) which quickly became a success and branched out into her writing poetry, writing for online magazines, blog sites and E.P.K’s for record labels artists. She mainly speaks about social and lifestyle issues centred around the black community in her blogs.

In 2019 she moved to Los Angeles for a year where she studied directing, screen and narrative writing and acting. She came back to London in 2020 aspiring to direct music videos and film. She has currently worked with UK artist Ay Em and Avelino, assistant directing their music video ‘Can't Wait ‘. She also directed upcoming artiste Vaiyzo’s music video ‘Flights’ which is coming out soon. 

 

Producer:

Destinee Poole is the co-writer and producer of the short film, ‘Our Day’. She's in her final year at San Francisco State University studying Cinema. Her background is in acting, producing, writing, and sound design which is the departments she works in within AAB. Destinee is very excited to be working on this project and values the message that it will send to the youth around the world.

Poole has always had an interest in collaborative filmmaking, her ultimate goal is to one day work with HBO studios. Her recent favourite shows include Euphoria, Big Little Lies and Search Party. She has always had a love for dark, drama films as well as documentaries, which are also the type of projects she wants to pursue in the future.

Outside of film, Poole has a passion for cooking, writing, and fashion styling. You can find her on Instagram at: _desss.p_

 

Line Producer:

Ekow Barnes is a curator/strategist with experience spanning both fashion communication and production. This hybrid background enables Ekow to operate at the intersection of brand strategy, creativity,  production and technology. Ekow believes brand-building in this post-digital world is about impactful, insight-driven brand communications and delightful, user-centric digital experiences. His vision is to change the narrative about Africa through the production of African stories to the world.

 

Videographer:

As a professional in the industry for 12 years, Joy Williams has made a name for himself in the Western and African film market as a prolific Director of Photography and director whose work has been recognised in the corporate and music video category.

Having a Masters degree in Broadcasting and Production, Joy has gained the skills and experience to create remarkable content. Having worked with directors like Meji Alabi, Andy Lambert, Joy has managed to capture the audience's attention through outstanding cinematography.

He has shot music videos, commercials and documentaries in several countries including Los Angeles, Miami, South Africa, Nigeria and Malawi to name a few. Joy has also shot videos for brands such as  MTN, British Airways and Dyson and artists including David Quetta, Akon, Stonebwoy and many more. 

 

Writers:

Effe Hozaifeh is a writer for AABproductions. Currently studying English literature at the University of Warwick, Effe has always dreamed of working behind the scenes in the film industry. Since joining AAB, Effe has helped with assistant directing, fundraising & casting. She also currently manages the AAB Instagram account.

Effe is a big fan of big-budget fiction (#teamMarvel) but also has a special place in her heart for telling stories that matter, giving voices to those whose own voices may not always be heard. She aspires to one day work on a movie (or two) set in the MCU as well as work on shows for Netflix, Amazon Prime Video and Disney Plus.

Outside of film she has her own hair page @trustyourcurls on Instagram, TikTok & Pinterest (@trustyourcurlsofficial).

Aaliyah Roberts is a writer for AAB productions and a current student at California State University Northridge where she will be awarded her Bachelors of Arts in screenwriting this spring. This coming fall she will be pursuing an MFA in screen and television writing at the University of Southern California within their prestigious school of cinematic arts.

Even though Aaliyah’s main focus is in screenwriting she dabbles in all forms of writing such as Poetry, short stories, and plays. No matter what form she is writing in her main goal is to always inspire and uplift her community. Being Black and Mexican she has always felt a strong need to be the voice of these marginalized groups who have interesting and compelling stories but aren’t always acknowledged because they aren’t deemed as marketable to mainstream audiences.

Aaliyah aspires to develop a show for Cartoon Network because she finds representation in children’s programming to be the most impactful as it can teach children racial and gender tolerance at an early age.

Outside of writing Aaliyah enjoys cuddling her cat and binge-watching the latest Shonda Rhimes drama or rewatching adventure time and reminiscing on her childhood days when her biggest worry was finding enough money to buy a bag of hot Cheetos. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Shooting a quality product is always a challenge, and now especially with the Covid-19 pandemic. Financial backing is absolutely essential to be able to make this film as with your funding and support, we will be able to cover all the necessities. These include paying the actors and the crew, sourcing props, creating costumes, and all location costs that we will come across. In addition to this, we will be able to source PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) such as Covid-19 testing, masks, hand sanitisers for all our cast and crew working on set. Donating to our project will help to open doors for local film creators and actors in Ghana who may not have the opportunity to make and share stories with the world. We thank you in advance for your support. 

Our Rewards for donating are as followed:

  • £10: General digital thank you letter. 
  • £35: Raffle Ticket (Contents: The Hat worn in the film, The Dress worn in the film, 'Our Day' film Hat, and 'Our Day' Film Hoodie. 
  • £100: 'Our Day'  Hoodie 
  • £300; free screening, a hat, a mask, and a hoodie. 
  • £1000 (5 people) - co-producer credit hoodie and hat early digital copy/ ticket of screening 
  • £5000 (2 people) - Executive producer, special thanks at the end of credit, hoodie, hat, early digital copy/. Personalized Thank you letter. 

 

The Impact

When we see black people on screen they are always struggling. Struggling to get out the hood, struggling for survival, or struggling in a world that is systematically set up against them. There is nothing wrong with these stories, there is a lot of truth to them but these aren’t our only stories. When AAB Productions think of black people, we think of happiness, strength, fun, laughter, and carefree energy. These are the themes we want to exemplify in our short film. Creating a coming of age story about young black kids exploring their feelings with their first crushes is important because we never see  Black kids being so innocently blissful of the world and people around them.

Your contribution will help bring this idea to fruition and hopefully inspire Black kids around the world because Black children need to know that their life isn’t all about struggle. They are allowed to be young and carefree, and not be so consumed by the evils of the world that unfortunately do surround them.

Our company relates to this story because we too are young Black and Persons of Color who are going into the film world with bright eyes and an unwavering sense of determination and curiosity. This is what being young is all about, taking risks and doing things for the sake of art. We thank you for understanding and can’t wait to make this project happen with your help.

 

Risks & Challenges

Some of the challenges and the risk that we will face are:

  • Money 
  • Travel 
  • Shooting abroad (not having everyone on the team on location) 
  • We’re all students (some of us graduating) 
  • Going into an industry that doesn’t value our voices 
  • We may not be considered “marketable” (the story)

Other Ways You Can Help

in addition to donating to our film, you can support us by:

  • Post on social media 
  • Support the film when it’s released
  • Follow us on social media (for updates) @aabproductions

We thank you all for your support in contributing to our amazing project. You are apart of this production and we value your donations highly.

story:
The Hologram is a dystopian Sci-fi independent short film set in a future where the global economy collapsed due to an Artificial Super Intelligence. This crisis resulted in a ban on ASI. Tech conglomerate Spectrum adapted by replacing AI technology with real people to become Holograms. Aka, your own personal Andy Serkis.

Max, our protagonist, is a disgruntled Motion capture performer wanting to better their standing in Spectrum and live a better life. Before that can happen, Max needs to be there for a range of dynamic and difficult clients whilst grasping on to a sense of true self. 

The film is a commentary on our symbiotic relationship with technology and how many of us still feel lonely despite the world being more connected than ever before. How does what we're exposed to online and how we choose to show our lives affect our personal psyche?

We are creators, young pioneers and aspiring professionals ready to make our mark on the world one story at a time. This story is one we're all passionate about sharing and collaborating with you all. Be part of our journey, help us grow and refine our vision to create a truly engaging piece of film. 

Your support means the world to us, by backing the project you're enabling us to see out our creative vision and make a professional final product. All production members are working voluntarily and giving their own time to develop the film, but time is still money and travel expenses, locations, VFX, props and costumes all need funding to make the piece the best it can be.  

We have been able to apply for £900 funding from our university, but are required to match that amount from other sources in order to actually receive the money from them. By supporting us on here, you're allowing us to unlock that amount by essentially doubling our independent film's budget.  This will greatly increase the quality and reach of our film upon release.  

Due to Covid-19, our final year at university and getting this project off the ground have both been stunted. With a pledge, you're giving us a ticket into the professional film industry after these dark times for film production.  Supporting us as young filmmakers will secure the future of the industry with a diverse range of creatives pursuing positive change in the stories we share and how we choose to make them. 

The story has come from the heart of our director and aims to raise awareness for current issues in society and have all viewers be left entertained and enlightened. By telling unique stories within the whole picture and utilising the metaphor of Science Fiction to mirror our real world the film sets out to connect deeply with the audience. 

CHARLIE AND LOLA'S STORY

In this plotline, Max play's Abigail, a carer for Ralph in the form of his young daughter. This story deals with Dignity, Family, Loss and Dementia. The dynamic of the two is perfect for exploring these themes a presenting a unique way of dealing with these issues whilst deeply feeling for the characters.

MAX AND SIMON'S STORY

In this plotline, Max play's Abigail, a carer for Ralph in the form of his young daughter. This story deals with Dignity, Family, Loss and Dementia. The dynamic of the two is perfect for exploring these themes a presenting a unique way of dealing with these issues whilst deeply feeling for the characters.

MAX AND SIMON'S STORY

In this plotline, we follow the mental toll Spectrum employees are exposed to with a penultimate showdown in a setting fitting for the themes presented in the story which are connection, equality and wealth. The reflection of Max in Simon is a poignant representation of the inner struggle for Max across the whole narrative.

We don't want to leave you empty-handed, so depending on the amount you pledge you'll get increasingly cool rewards.  What are these you ask...? These are your Happy Level's, Spectrum's way of measuring how valuable an employee is to us. Check em out here!

Pledge Perks

  1. Happy Level 15: An A5 Film Postcard signed with a thank you message.
  2. Happy Level 25: A signed A3 Film poster.
  3. Happy Level 50: Ticket to the Early Virtual Screening of the film, your name in the credits and a custom Spectrum Business Card.
  4. Happy Level 75:  Ticket to the Early Virtual Screening of the film, your name in the credits and a digital copy of the final film including Behind the scenes.
  5. Happy Level 100: Your name in the film's credits, a signed A2 poster of the film and a DVD copy of the film including Behind the Scenes.
  6. Happy Level 150: Tickets to the film's premiere in Bristol or London, your name in the credits, a DVD copy of the film including Behind the scenes, an A2 signed poster of the film and a custom Spectrum business card.

As mentioned, your money will go towards all aspects of production, but here's some more specifics to put your mind at ease. ..

  • Locations: The film features 4 key and distinct locations, including one which will have to be a purpose-built set (which we're very excited about). The costs of using, insuring, travelling to, building and dressing these, sets all costs. So a large portion of the money will be going towards making this possible.
  • Costumes: With a diverse roster of characters, each with their own unique look and none more so than our protagonist Max. We want to create a custom and sleek looking motion capture suit for Max to wear throughout the film. The mesh of Holograms and Motion Capture is at the core of the film's narrative, so we want this costume to be a seamless centrepiece. The design, development and maintenance of the costumes will all be funded by your support. 
  • Food: Often overlooked, but still an important part of our budget, is having the money to feed our cast and crew. A hungry set is a grumpy set and we need everyone at the top of their game, to give you all the film you deserve. So a portion of a budget will go towards on set catering, so we can keep those talented bellies full.
  • VFX: We want to push our VFX and mesh reality and CGI seamlessly to immerse you all in the story. We are planning on using multiple plug-ins and elements to make this happen which all cost. We're also treading new ground by integrating AI machine learning to aid a VFX pipeline. Check out this pioneering software here: https://runwayml.com/
  • Distribution: Once the film is done, the work doesn't stop. Getting our film to you and other costs. We are planning on employing a Sales Agent with our funds to get our films to festivals and on screens around the world. As well as hosting our own premiere in Bristol and London and releasing the original soundtrack on music streaming platforms.

 

If we're not able to reach our goal, the funds we make will be distributed across these different production aspects and as we won't be able to acquire the other half of the budget from our university, we will create a revised budget. We will make the project as intended and will just have to come up with creative solutions and cutbacks to complete.  Luckily problem-solving is in our training, so we'd be able to figure it out with cash from our own pockets. Ideally, we want the full budget to make our vision to the highest standard.

The biggest risk the production faces is COVID-19, however in light of the pandemic we've pushed back principal photography to August so we can have more freedom with restrictions. We will be shooting a proof of concept in April to get you all excited and give a glimpse of what's to come. We've all been trained in covid safety regulations on set by our university. With your help and support we'll be able to overcome any risks that come our way. 

If you're unable to pledge, you can support us by sharing our project on social media or telling your friends and family. Getting the word out about the film is just as helpful as a pledge. Indiegogo has easy to use share tools, so please feel free to use them. 

We can't wait for you to join us on our adventure into the world of THE HOLOGRAM...

The reflection of Max in Simon is a poignant representation of the inner struggle for Max across the whole narrative.

We don't want to leave you empty-handed, so depending on the amount you pledge you'll get increasingly cool rewards.  What are these you ask...? These are your Happy Level's, Spectrum's way of measuring how valuable an employee is to us. Check em out here!
Pledge Perks


Happy Level 15: An A5 Film Postcard signed with a thank you message.

Happy Level 25: A signed A3 Film poster.

Happy Level 50: Ticket to the Early Virtual Screening of the film, your name in the credits and a custom Spectrum Business Card.

Happy Level 75:  Ticket to the Early Virtual Screening of the film, your name in the credits and a digital copy of the final film including Behind the scenes.

Happy Level 100: Your name in the film's credits, a signed A2 poster of the film and a DVD copy of the film including Behind the Scenes.

Happy Level 150: Tickets to the film's premiere in Bristol or London, your name in the credits, a DVD copy of the film including Behind the scenes, an A2 signed poster of the film and a custom Spectrum business card.


As mentioned, your money will go towards all aspects of production, but here's some more specifics to put your mind at ease. ..


Locations: The film features 4 key and distinct locations, including one which will have to be a purpose-built set (which we're very excited about). The costs of using, insuring, travelling to, building and dressing these, sets all costs. So a large portion of the money will be going towards making this possible.

Costumes: With a diverse roster of characters, each with their own unique look and none more so than our protagonist Max. We want to create a custom and sleek looking motion capture suit for Max to wear throughout the film. The mesh of Holograms and Motion Capture is at the core of the film's narrative, so we want this costume to be a seamless centrepiece. The design, development and maintenance of the costumes will all be funded by your support. 

Food: Often overlooked, but still an important part of our budget, is having the money to feed our cast and crew. A hungry set is a grumpy set and we need everyone at the top of their game, to give you all the film you deserve. So a portion of a budget will go towards on set catering, so we can keep those talented bellies full.

VFX: We want to push our VFX and mesh reality and CGI seamlessly to immerse you all in the story. We are planning on using multiple plug-ins and elements to make this happen which all cost. We're also treading new ground by integrating AI machine learning to aid a VFX pipeline. Check out this pioneering software here: https://runwayml.com/


Distribution: Once the film is done, the work doesn't stop. Getting our film to you and other costs. We are planning on employing a Sales Agent with our funds to get our films to festivals and on screens around the world. As well as hosting our own premiere in Bristol and London and releasing the original soundtrack on music streaming platforms.

 
If we're not able to reach our goal, the funds we make will be distributed across these different production aspects and as we won't be able to acquire the other half of the budget from our university, we will create a revised budget. We will make the project as intended and will just have to come up with creative solutions and cutbacks to complete.  Luckily problem-solving is in our training, so we'd be able to figure it out with cash from our own pockets. Ideally, we want the full budget to make our vision to the highest standard.


The biggest risk the production faces is COVID-19, however in light of the pandemic we've pushed back principal photography to August so we can have more freedom with restrictions. We will be shooting a proof of concept in April to get you all excited and give a glimpse of what's to come. We've all been trained in covid safety regulations on set by our university. With your help and support we'll be able to overcome any risks that come our way. 

If you're unable to pledge, you can support us by sharing our project on social media or telling your friends and family. Getting the word out about the film is just as helpful as a pledge. Indiegogo has easy to use share tools, so please feel free to use them. 
We can't wait for you to join us on our adventure into the world of THE HOLOGRAM...

story:
SYNOPSIS: In the haunted October of 1977, people are disappearing. An investigation reveals the dark and disturbing truth… a nightmarish cult of witches is responsible. Now, one family has hired a tracker to find their daughters, and take on the unspeakable horror within the coven

THE CAST

Brinke Stevens (The Slumber Party Massacre)


 

Jennifer Stone, Todd Jenkins, Auriel Balistreri, Paula Marcenaro Solinger

story:
EN Media could not be more grateful for all of your generosity - we reached our goal!  And because we did, we are thrilled that we are able to keep our campaign open for another six months.  Breaking our 20,000 dollar goal was incredible for us, but money does go quickly when you're makin' a movie.  Any additional contributions will go to post-production, festival submission costs and future ventures of EN Media.  

"Care" is a SAG short film which wrapped production last week in Blue Ridge, Georgia.  This is the first official production from EN Media, executive produced by Evan Enslow, written by Erin Anne MacDonald and directed by Paul D. Mooney.

Inspiration

Covid-19 turned all of our worlds upside down, but none so much as those of our front-line workers.  While all of us adjusted to quarantine and a new social norm, our interpersonal relationships were put to the test at the cost of loneliness and isolation.  We fought to balance our sanity with our physical health.  It wasn't easy.  (Nah, actually - it sucked.)

The story of "Care":

In 2023, an ICU nurse is falsely accused of manslaughter due to negligence in the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Share

Please share this ongoing campaign on social media and with anyone you think might want to be involved with telling this impactful story or support the future of EN Media.

Thank you so much!

story:
"Deep Clean"

Before you read this. Watch our teaser trailer, linked above, which provides some backstory to the world we are inhabiting in our filmic universe.

Through contributing to this subversive and challenging narrative, you are aiding us in bringing forth our team's vision to the big screen. Here are some key points about our film:

  • Based in and around London, UK
  • Made by up and coming artists who are breakthrough talents within their respective fields 
  • Will be a project aimed at supporting students breaking through into the film industry by providing opportunities in a number of roles.
  • The team are ambitious and are aiming high: in particular through a fruitful festival run and the potential for awards.

So what is this whole story about?

Synopsis

Set in a world where the state of your soul is visible to everyone through large black stains that materialise on your clothing.  You can visit laundrettes in order to wash your soul free from the pain harboured in everyday life. These institutions both remove the black stains from your clothes, making you appear visibly cleansed however, also free you from the pain associated with the actions that caused your soul to be blackened and thus also morally cleanse you.  This of course comes at a hefty monetary fee.  

Our main Character Soap is a frequent of these locations and is beginning to feel the negative consequences of "over-washing" your soul. The film follows him as he journeys through this dystopia trying to break free from the "rat race" society has imposed on him. Taking steps to break the cycle and become an individual again.

Intention

The world we created raises multiple moral questions that we seek to address through our film.

  • How would people behave if they were no longer morally reprehensible for their actions?
  • How would peoples outward appearances change due to the impact of your soul being visible to everyone, would there be a pressure to always appear clean?
  • What would happen if you could not afford to use these specialised laundrettes, would emotions such as guilt, anxiety and pain be emotions exclusively imposed on the poorer members of society?
  • Who would be exploited in this societal structure?
  • Would there be much change at all?

We delve deeper and provide our interpretations to these questions through the dynamics presented between the characters in our script however, we aim for our film to make YOU think and question your own responses to these stimuli. 

Meet The Team

Luis Conte: Director, Co-Writer

Luis is an Anglo-Italian film writer and director. He is particularly interested in producing screen content that challenges the status quo and that seeks to encourage positive changes in the world. He thrives within the subversive and has a particular interest in works containing magical realism as a vehicle to explore larger world defining concepts. Coming from the background of an undergraduate degree in English Literature from one of the top universities in the country, he possesses a skill set that allows him to understand the deeper nuances within art and explore them with greater care. Luis also has experience directing music videos for up-and-coming artists; advertisements for large commercial brands such as Lush, and narrative fiction, that he has both written and been given. He is ambitious and has an innate desire to be successful. He is most certainly someone who should be on your “one to watch list.”

Federico Arosio: Producer

Federico is an Italian film producer from Milan. He is particularly interested in producing films that reflect the wider world and societal issues through a plethora of unique voices. He has studied in multiple countries across Europe as well as explored large parts of South America with just himself and his backpack. This has grounded him and given him worldly experiences that he can draw upon in the production room. Fede (as he likes to be called), has also set up and ran his own production company back in Rome, called “Elodia Cinematografica” and as a result has produced and been crew on several projects in the Italian film world. He also has a master’s degree in law, which gives him the materials to embark on the more formal processes of filmmaking with skill and efficiency.

Giulio Amendolagine: Director of Photography

Giulio is an Italian Cinematographer who is currently living in England. He is particularly interested in character driven stories that utilise surrealism or magical realism to deliver a message about the current composition of the world today. Giulio has a diverse portfolio working alongside several directors: filming scenes for narrative, interviews and adverts and has a strong diverse skill set. He has experience with both professional and non-professional actors and thrives in the challenges of making a film. Giulio is a previous co-collaborator with Luis shooting interviews for the large commercial brand Lush, and thus they are keen to work together again.
Link to showreel: https://vimeo.com/577184197

 

Raphael D'Cruz: Screenwriter

Raphael is a London based creative who has several completed scripts to his name. He mainly writes crime fiction, thrillers and action-based narratives. He likes to underpin his narratives with a stringent social lens which can only be honed by living in South London. He aims to appeal to people who fall under the category of Millennial/Gen Z by evoking a sense of modernity within his writing, challenging issues that are current and prominent within our world today. He has decided to team up with Luis and co-write this narrative as an expression of their combined view of today’s political landscape and how perhaps people of their age can stand up and make a difference.

Style

The film is to adopt a style inspired by several social defining films of their time. The depiction of the world will be centred in a gritty naturalism and focus on the harsh realities of everyday life.

The film will be a part of the British filmmaking tradition and therefore, it will look and sound like the people who inhabit the home nations. Therefore, the true sense of multiculturality and diversity, found in the British Isles, will be shown through how the characters look and sound. In short, you will know a character is a Londoner by their looks and mannerisms.

Each scene will be meticulously story boarded, giving the film a distinctive "look" where shots throughout will parallel each-other and have a strong subtextual message which will be delivered through the cinematography.

 

Budget Breakdown

We already have a base of funds. However, we do need some supplementary help from YOU for these main areas: 

  • £1600 – Actors (to supplement existing funds)
  • £800 – Locations
  • £200 – Catering
  • £100 – Art Department
  • £100 – Make Up Department
  • £150 – Costume Department
  • £200 – Transport
  • £400 – Contingency

Total: £3550

Other Ways You Can Help

Not all of you will be able to contribute to "Deep Clean" monetarily, however you can aid us by sharing this link on your social media, amongst your friends and family, and by simply talking about the project, One share not only increases our overall reach, but also helps us appear in the sites algorithm!

We are grateful for help in any way you can. Please do help us make this dream a reality!
