story:
Note: Donations from the U.S. and Canada are eligible to receive charitable tax receipts. 

Let's unite together to help heal the wounds of war, violence and oppression and create a bright future for the world!

August 2015 represents the 70th anniversary of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. This summer the Earth Caravan will travel to places which have suffered trauma and violence, in order to help heal the wounds of war, violence and disaster. 

The Caravan will begin its sojourn in Hiroshima on its way to Tokyo and Kyoto; bringing with it a message for the end of nuclear weapons and the end of global military expenditure. 

It will then travel to Europe, holding peace and healing festivals in Vienna, Prague and Munich, with special stops in Auschwitz and Dachau concentration camps.

This year, the Caravan will conclude its journey in Israel and the West Bank. There it will bring together Israelis, Palestinians and internationals who will embark on an eight day voyage of peace, healing, and bearing witness to the pain and trauma on both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict; and send a universal interfaith message of peace, freedom and justice for all.

The Earth Caravan is an interfaith pilgrimage whose mission is to share peace, happiness and healing in the world through words, art, music and inter-religious prayers and meditation. The Caravan was conceived by the members of Tao Sangha, a Buddhist non-governmental organization founded by the internationally renowned Buddhist priest and master of Tao Shiatsu, Ryokyu Endo (www.taosangha-na.com).


What We Need & What You Get

Local support for the Caravan has been inspiring. But now we need your help, so that the Caravan's message of hope, peace and freedom will spread to as many people as possible and be heard for many years to come.

50% of the money you give will be used exclusively for costs associated with bringing the Caravan and its message to life, like the creation and maintenance of our website, for audio/visual equipment needed to document the Caravan, and for travel expenses of our volunteer coordinators, many of whom have contributed their own money toward these ends. The organizers of the Earth Caravan are all volunteers, so there are no salaries to pay. Your donation will also help the Caravan continue its activities in 2016 and beyond. 

The other 50% of the funds you donate will be used to help projects that support children's education in Rwanda, Jewish-Arab kindergartens in Israel and children's aid projects in Palestine.

We have wonderful perks to offer you that make your contribution more than worthwhile! They include downloads of the Earth Caravan album SHARE!, hardcopy albums from Ryokyu Endo (the founder of Tao Shiatsu) and his band Lamani, original works of art, reserved places on the Earth Caravan Europe and Mideast voyages, and many more. 

We need your help achieving our goal. Indiegogo charges a 9.0% fee on the funds we raise. If we reach our goal, we will get 6.0% back, for an overall fee of 3.0%. This is a significant difference! We hope you will help us reach that goal and beyond!

The Impact

By giving to the Earth Caravan, you’ll be contributing directly to touching people’s hearts and to sowing the seeds of hope for a brighter future for the world, for this year and beyond.

Deep inside every person exists the wish to care about somebody, the wish for peace, happiness and a good future for the planet.  We believe as human beings that sharing happiness, freedom and justice is possible.

By expressing each person's wish, through words, art, music, meditation and prayers and sharing it with each other on a global scale, we hope to bring healing energy to places that still carry the wounds of war and violence and where people still suffer.

We want the earth to be healed from the trauma and the violent karma of past centuries. We pray for a new future of living together in harmony and ease.

So many people wish for peace. Why not believe that it will be the Earth’s reality?

Risks & Challenges

Planning this year's Caravan and those of 2016 and beyond is a huge challenge, especially with no budget and minimal resources. By donating to our campaign, you'll help give us that solid financial foundation that we absolutely need to make this year's Caravan a success and to plan for the Earth Caravan 2016.

Help by Donating

Donate whatever amount you can. The Earth Caravan is a one of a kind project that will touch many hearts and help change the violent course of history!

Donate by Cheque

You may donate by cheque! 

In North America:

Please make your cheque out to Tao Sangha and mail to:

Tao Sangha Healing Center
2330 Willard Ave. 
Madison, WI, USA 53704
In Europe:

Please make your cheque out to Amida Tao Sangha Zentrum and mail to:

Amida Tao Sangha Zentrum
Neubaugasse 12-14/2/14
Austria - 1070 Wien


Who Can I Contact?

For more information about this project, please get in touch with us:

  • By email: info@earthcaravan.net
  • By Twitter: @earthcaravan
  • On Facebook
You may also contact Lawrence Lefcort (lawrence@taosangha-na.com), Deborah Bachmann (deb@taosangha-na.com), Magali Brosh (magali.brosh@gmail.com), Alfred Mueller (alf.mueller@aon.at).

Can I Receive a Charitable Tax Receipt if I donate?

YES! We can offer U.S. and Canadian residents charitable tax receipts in US dollars, issued via Common Arts, USA. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand that some of you may not be able to contribute with financial support but that doesn't mean you can't help our campaign! Please help spread the word and make some noise about our campaign through friends, family and loved ones! Check out the indiegogo share tools to help do so.

Please help us to continue this sharing!

THANK YOU ALL SO MUCH!
story_txt:
Note: Donations from the U.S. and Canada are eligible to receive charitable tax receipts. 
Let's unite together to help heal the wounds of war, violence and oppression and create a bright future for the world!
August 2015 represents the 70th anniversary of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. This summer the Earth Caravan will travel to places which have suffered trauma and violence, in order to help heal the wounds of war, violence and disaster. 
The Caravan will begin its sojourn in Hiroshima on its way to Tokyo and Kyoto; bringing with it a message for the end of nuclear weapons and the end of global military expenditure. 




It will then travel to Europe, holding peace and healing festivals in Vienna, Prague and Munich, with special stops in Auschwitz and Dachau concentration camps.


This year, the Caravan will conclude its journey in Israel and the West Bank. There it will bring together Israelis, Palestinians and internationals who will embark on an eight day voyage of peace, healing, and bearing witness to the pain and trauma on both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict; and send a universal interfaith message of peace, freedom and justice for all.



The Earth Caravan is an interfaith pilgrimage whose mission is to share peace, happiness and healing in the world through words, art, music and inter-religious prayers and meditation. The Caravan was conceived by the members of Tao Sangha, a Buddhist non-governmental organization founded by the internationally renowned Buddhist priest and master of Tao Shiatsu, Ryokyu Endo (www.taosangha-na.com).

   What We Need & What You Get 
Local support for the Caravan has been inspiring. But now we need your help, so that the Caravan's message of hope, peace and freedom will spread to as many people as possible and be heard for many years to come.

50% of the money you give will be used exclusively for costs associated with bringing the Caravan and its message to life, like the creation and maintenance of our website, for audio/visual equipment needed to document the Caravan, and for travel expenses of our volunteer coordinators, many of whom have contributed their own money toward these ends. The organizers of the Earth Caravan are all volunteers, so there are no salaries to pay. Your donation will also help the Caravan continue its activities in 2016 and beyond. 
The other 50% of the funds you donate will be used to help projects that support children's education in Rwanda, Jewish-Arab kindergartens in Israel and children's aid projects in Palestine.


We have wonderful perks to offer you that make your contribution more than worthwhile! They include downloads of the Earth Caravan album SHARE!, hardcopy albums from Ryokyu Endo (the founder of Tao Shiatsu) and his band Lamani, original works of art, reserved places on the Earth Caravan Europe and Mideast voyages, and many more. 

We need your help achieving our goal. Indiegogo charges a 9.0% fee on the funds we raise. If we reach our goal, we will get 6.0% back, for an overall fee of 3.0%. This is a significant difference! We hope you will help us reach that goal and beyond! So many people wish for peace. Why not believe that it will be the Earth’s reality?







   Risks & Challenges  Planning this year's Caravan and those of 2016 and beyond is a huge challenge, especially with no budget and minimal resources. By donating to our campaign, you'll help give us that solid financial foundation that we absolutely need to make this year's Caravan a success and to plan for the Earth Caravan 2016.

story:
2016 Election

We have been filming since August 2014.  Our cameras are falling apart, and not up to the task.  We need new/better equipment to make a truly great theatrical movie that will appeal to the masses.  Please help us do this!

I think very few people know who the REAL candidates are, but I will find out who they really are and show the American people 6 weeks before the general election. The Nominee is a behind the scenes theatrical movie about ALL of the Presidential candidates. Hillary Clinton alone is going to spend $2.5 billion on this election. My production budget is a fraction of a percent of that. Help fund The Nominee and I will present TRUTH at a crucial time in our country's history. If you donate, you will not only get a perk, you might just help to make a change! Please share this and contact me directly for details If you want to talk serious money, more than a donation, I'm set up for investors as well.  I will meet privately with you and I will show you exclusive footage and talk details. montegoodyk@gmail.com or call me. 641-417-8092 Text or Face time are fine too!

story:
What It's About

Many immigrant groups have a long and well-documented history of their migration to Canada, but little has been told about the Indonesian community, which migrated to Canada as early as the 1950s.

Taking inspiration from Vancouver Asian Heritage Month’s “First Families, First Stories” project, the Canada Indonesia Diaspora Society wants to collect the stories of our pioneer families that explores their immigration experience: their settlement and integration, their participation in everyday life, and their religious affectations.

Through the crowdfunding campaign, we hope to be able to access audio, visual and other resources, which, when completed, will add a colourful contribution to a multicultural Canada.

We want to preserve, document, and make available a book and a travelling exhibition.

We want to revive the voyage of the first families — their own stories in their own words.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funds to publish a historical book that tells first families' stories
  • Resources to compile a travelling exhibit: photos, documents, sound installations and artefacts relating to Indonesian migration

The Impact

The Canada Indonesia Diaspora Society wants to build the Indonesian community's legacy with this oral history project. It aims to connect first, second and future generations of Indonesian-Canadians to their heritage through the stories of their ancestors. 

Digging into the diverse roots of Chinese, Malaysian, and Eurasian Indonesians, the project documents the struggle of a people divided by war, colonialism, and scattered immigration.

story:
Short Summary

The Our Children, Climate, Faith Symposium was founded to create and further the connection between faith, spirituality, and religion, and acting on climate disruption. Reverend Byron Breese is an ordained Baptist minister, with a strong history in pluralism. Jeff Wolfe is a long time solar entrepreneur and climate activist.

The basis of the symposium is that all spiritualities and faiths are rooted in work for social justice and deep care for our children. Recognizing that climate disruption will be the largest creator of social injustice, especially against our children, we believe that working to fight climate disruption is central to a life of faith and spirituality.

Over our first two years (2013 and 2014, I misspoke in the video!) we achieved much. We found out that our thesis was new, had not been discussed. When we created the conversation, people of many faiths and spiritualities listened. People in environmental movements listened. We now are beginning to hear that faith and spirituality have a role to play in motivating action for many people. But our work is far from over. More and larger groups are hearing our message. We have reached Unitarians, Congregationalists, Baptists, Muslims, Buddhists, Pagans, Wiccans, Native Americans, and Spiritualists. We are beginning to reach even more faiths, from southeast Sikh to Protestant Fundamentalist. And we are uncovering an associated need of activists, for grieving, recovery, and long term support.

We normally raise our funds by winning a couple low 4-figure grants, quite a few small donations from friends, and registration fees ($75 or what you can afford). We are non-profit (all funds go through our local Unitarian Universalist Church and are tax deductible) But this year we are adding:

 - a 2 day overnight Young Adult Summit where 18-30 year olds will share stories, train, and teach each other in climate activism while exploring their own spiritual connections, guided or individually.

 - a 2 day camp program for pre-K to 17 year olds, making it easier for families to attend the symposium.

See our website for more information on current and past programs. www.FaithClimateConference.org

We have already achieved so much with very little. That's why we're not looking for much here, we will do a lot with a little more. Every dollar is amplified by 20x compared to any other symposium I have been involved in, due to donations of time, talent, and resources.

We have already changed the conversation. Help us to drive that change further, for a better, more just planet, for our children.

What We Need & What You Get

The symposium costs about $13,500 to put on. The Youth Summit is budgeted at $2000. The children's program is budgeted at $1000. Those costs break down as follows:

Symposium
$3500 - Facilities (Tent, chairs, tables, Strafford Town House, porta-potties, etc.)
$7500 - Food (We try to be organic and local, and use reusable/compostable dishware, and we need a coordinator on site to keep us clean and safe)
$750 - Marketing (website hosting/domain, posters, ads)
$1750 - Transportation (some of our speakers do not have the means to come from a distance. We pay modest travel. Everyone does homestays for a room.)

Young Adult Summit
$500 - Facilities, $1000 - Food, $500 - Supplies

Children's Program
$250 - Facilities, $400 - Food & Supplies, $350 - Director (our one paid person. We want the children with a professional, along with the volunteers!)

The total budget is $16,500. We have raised $3000 to-date for this year, and we expect to raise another $2000 locally. That leaves us here, asking for $4000.

 - If we fall short of our goal, we will still hold the events, but will continue fundraising after the event to pay the bills. This will jeopardize the 2016 event.

 - If we raise more than required, we will use the extra to further expand the symposium during 2015 and 2016. Satellite symposiums, other venues for spreading our work (we present at the Parliament of the World's Religions in October). We are working to bring on a part time Director for 2016, as we know this critical work can blossom with more support.

The Impact

Byron has built an interfaith center, which continues that critical work after 20 years. Jeff has built a national solar company and influenced policy and legislation throughout the US. Everyone on the steering committee has successful efforts, and the 2013 and 2014 Symposiums were both hailed as amazing successes. Help this team to further this work.

Risks & Challenges

We have each individually and collectively faced many challenges. Although we have four outstanding keynote speakers on board, we may note be able to get enough registrations to have the symposium be a rousing spiritual, activist, and financial success. As we each have throughout our careers and lives, we will work tirelessly to have that not happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need, and appreciate, any contribution. A few dollars, many dollars, or a bunch of shout outs and shares (use the Indiegogo tools!) Anything helps. 

Remember, it's not our planet, it's our children's. Give, so we can give to them.

Thank you. Peace to you.

story:
日本語訳はこちら！

Welcome everyone and thank you for visiting our page.  Our names are Erik Svare and Jon Chamberlain. Gekka is an artist collective based in Osaka, Japan.  Together we create unique designs and hand screen them onto clothing and accessories. We help orphans around the world support each other by contributing 20% of our proceeds to Ashinaga. 

Ashinaga is an organization that provides educational opportunities to orphaned children in Japan as well as internationally.  Since their beginning, Ashinaga has provided scholarships to more than 35,000 orphaned children.  They have recently done a lot to help the many children who lost their families in Tohoku Earthquake and Tsunami in 2011.  Jon had this to say:

"When I first discovered Ashinaga online, I spent a few hours reading through their website and articles about them.  One thing that jumped out at me was that they are pretty transparent.  They've been around a long time and there's a reason they have such a solid reputation.  Another thing I love about them is their support of orphaned children not just in Japan but also overseas.  On many occasions, they bring kids over from other countries and provide them with what they need to get a solid education in Japan.  That will in turn lead to a stronger and more diverse population and really help shape the future of this country.  A little more on them; before I was willing to donate to them, I wanted to meet someone at their office and make sure they were good people, so I took a trip to Tokyo.  I was really glad to see that their offices are humble and practical and not full of unnecessary frills.  They were also really nice people in general.  We went out for coffee after our meeting and I left with a feeling that these were the right people to give to."

If you'd like to learn more about Ashinaga and read their official website, please check out http://www.ashinaga.org/en/.  Don't just take our word for it!


Gekka is the result of two people meeting and discovering a common interest in charity and creativity.  Founder Jon Chamberlain, met creative director Erik Svare when he needed some custom t-shirts made for a party.  After meeting with Erik at his original brand shop (Viva La Mort), Jon fell in love with the creative design work and the inspiration behind each piece.  Amazingly, Jon was looking for a designer at that time to help him build an idea.  The idea was a grass roots, creativity driven project that would result in being able to give back to a worthy cause.  A few months down the road, Gekka came to life. 

We decided to call our brand Gekka (which means "under the moon" in Japanese). We love the imagery that the word brings, representing something mystical and beautiful, blooming in the night.


When thinking about the work at Ashinaga, and everything that they do for orphans around the world, we came up with this analogy:

The sun is representative of love, and more specifically, parental love. As the parents of the orphaned children are no longer tangible; the sun is out of view, but still in existence. It's power and light are real, and though it's heat can't be directly felt, it can still be seen and appreciated by the reflected light on the moon. This love and light is then passed on to the children. Gekka. 月下。"Under the Moon."

PERKS!

Gekka T-Shirts

NEW PERK! Sunbird Tee and Tote by DAAS.

NEW! Be Brave by Emi.

Gekka Hoodies 

Gekka Kids 

Gekka Tote Bags

Thanks to the great people at Crosley Radio, we are able to offer a Crosley Cruiser Portable Turntable that we've customized with a hand screened Gekka logo. Thank you again to Crosley and we are excited to see who will pick up this one of a kind reward. Learn more about Crosley Radio's products at  www.crosleyradio.com 



Gekka is in the process of collaborating with other artists from all over the world to create an ongoing stream of creativity.  Erik said this about collaboration: "I would love to be able to work with all kinds of artists on this project, which I think could be beneficial to all parties involved, not to mention fun! I want to present each artists name next to their design in the web shop, and on hang tags in physical stores, to give them credit for their work and move away from the typical anonymously designed tee. We can help them, they can help us, and together we can help kids. That is awesome!"  Erik's designs are all hand drawn, only using the computer to create a digital file from the original drawing. Silk screens are then made and the graphics are hand screened onto the clothing in our shop.  Please take a look for yourself at what we have come up with so far! Click HERE for a gallery of all of our products in high resolution!

Durga San Hand Painted Silk Screen Print


Our Durga San design is inspired by the Hindu Mother Goddess re-imagined with elements and symbols of Japanese childhood. 

Burgundy Durga San T-Shirt


We need to raise money to help us further our dream of building our brand here in Japan, with plans to expand in the future.  We are now a small operation and hope to grow, and spread awareness about our brand, and mission as far as possible. We also would like to make our own shapes and patterns for t-shirts, hoodies, bags, etc., using locally sourced fabrics and working with manufacturers, and designers in Japan. 

 Your contributions will directly be supporting:

- Orphans all over the world via Ashinaga

- Our production costs

- Marketing to expand our reach

- Development of future products (We're just getting started!)


We have big plans to continue creating unique new clothing while trying to make an impact on the world.  Supporting us is more than just buying cool stuff.  It means you support the idea of social entrepreneurship and believe in a system that allows great ideas to not just help one, but many.  With your help, Gekka has the potential to keep growing and do a lot of good throughout the world.  Everybody starts somewhere and everyone needs some form of support at the beginning.  Your support takes us from an idea, to a reality.  We really appreciate you taking the time to be here and look forward to having you be part of our team.  Let's do this!

Feel free to contact either one of us with any questions you might have at any time!  We will get back to you very quickly and we also just love hearing from people!  In the meantime, here are a few of the questions we've been asked already.

Where do you ship to? - Everywhere!  We can ship to any country in the world. Shipping internationally from Japan can be a little expensive but we've done our best to keep it as low as possible. Shipping prices are included in reward descriptions and must be added on the next page.  All shipping is express and includes tracking and insurance.

What does "Gekka" mean? - Gekka (月下) literally translates to "under the moon" from Japanese.  We used this as inspiration for our name, logo, and story.

How do I choose which items and sizes I want? - After the campaign is over, we will be sending you a link to a page where you can choose the ones you want!

Are Japanese sizes different? - Japanese sizes tend to be a bit smaller than Western sizes.  When choosing your items, it is a good idea to choose one size larger than you would usually in Western countries.

Can you use chopsticks? - YES!

We are so excited and grateful that you took the time to look at our campaign page. If you believe in what we are trying to do, please share it with your friends in any way that you can to help us make this dream a reality!  Don't forget to follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for more updates in the future.  One last thing... Smile big!

日本語訳はこちら！

 Another thing I love about them is their support of orphaned children
not just in Japan but also overseas.  On many occasions, they bring kids
over from other countries and provide them with what they need to get a
solid education in Japan.  That will in turn lead to a stronger and
more diverse population and really help shape the future of this country.
 A little more on them; before I was willing to donate to them, I
wanted to meet someone at their office and make sure they were good
people, so I took a trip to Tokyo.  I was really glad to see that their offices are humble and
practical and not full of unnecessary frills.  They were also really
nice people in general.  We went out for coffee after our meeting and I left with
a feeling that these were the right people to give to."

If you'd like
to learn more about Ashinaga and read their official website, please check
out http://www.ashinaga.org/en/.  Don't
just take our word for it!
Gekka is the result of two people meeting and discovering a
common interest in charity and creativity.  Founder Jon Chamberlain, met
creative director Erik Svare when he needed some custom t-shirts made for a
party.  After meeting with Erik at his original brand shop (Viva La Mort), Jon fell in
love with the creative design work and the inspiration behind each piece. 
Amazingly, Jon was looking for a designer at that time to help him build an
idea.  The idea was a grass roots, creativity driven project that would
result in being able to give back to a worthy cause.  A few months down
the road, Gekka came to life. We decided to call our brand Gekka (which means "under the moon" in Japanese). We love the imagery that the word brings, representing something mystical and beautiful, blooming in the night.
When thinking about the work at Ashinaga, and everything that they do for orphans around the world, we came up with this analogy:The sun is representative of love, and more specifically, parental love. As the parents of the orphaned children are no longer tangible; the sun is out of view, but still in existence. It's power and light are real, and though it's heat can't be directly felt, it can still be seen and appreciated by the reflected light on the moon. This love and light is then passed on to the children. Gekka. 月下。"Under the Moon."PERKS!
Gekka T-ShirtsNEW PERK! Sunbird Tee and Tote by DAAS.

NEW! Be Brave by Emi.Gekka Hoodies 
Gekka Kids 


Gekka Tote Bags
Thanks to the great people at Crosley Radio, we are able to offer a Crosley Cruiser Portable Turntable that we've customized with a hand screened Gekka logo. Thank you again to Crosley and we are excited to see who will pick up this one of a kind reward. Learn more about Crosley Radio's products at  www.crosleyradio.com 


Gekka is in the process of collaborating with other artists from
all over the world to create an ongoing stream of creativity.  Erik said this about collaboration: "I would love to be able to work with all kinds of artists on this project, which I think could be beneficial to all parties involved, not to mention fun! I want to present each artists name next to their design in the web shop, and on hang tags in physical stores, to give them credit for their work and move away from the typical anonymously designed tee. We can help them, they can help us, and together we can help kids. That is awesome!"  Erik's designs are all hand drawn, only using the computer to create a digital file from the original drawing. Silk screens are then made and the graphics are hand screened
onto the clothing in our shop.  Please take a look for yourself at what we
have come up with so far! Click HERE for a gallery of all of our products in high resolution!


Durga San Hand Painted Silk Screen Print

Our Durga San design is inspired by the Hindu Mother Goddess re-imagined with elements and symbols of Japanese childhood. 


Burgundy Durga San T-Shirt

We need to raise money to help
us further our dream of building our brand here in Japan, with plans to expand
in the future.  We are now a small operation and hope to grow, and spread
awareness about our brand, and mission as far as possible. We also would like to make our own shapes and patterns for t-shirts, hoodies, bags, etc., using locally sourced fabrics and working with manufacturers, and designers in Japan. 
 Your contributions will directly be supporting:
- Orphans all over the world via Ashinaga
- Our production costs
- Marketing to expand our
reach
- Development of future
products (We're just getting started!)


We have big plans to continue
creating unique new clothing while trying to make an impact on the world.
 Supporting us is more than just buying cool stuff.  It means you
support the idea of social entrepreneurship and believe in a system that allows
great ideas to not just help one, but many.  With your help, Gekka has the
potential to keep growing and do a lot of good throughout the world.
 Everybody starts somewhere and everyone needs some form of support at the
beginning.  Your support takes us from an idea, to a reality.  We
really appreciate you taking the time to be here and look forward to having you
be part of our team.  Let's do this!


Feel free to contact either one of us with any questions you might have at any time!  We will get back to you very quickly and we also just love hearing from people!  In the meantime, here are a few of the questions we've been asked already.
Where do you ship to? - Everywhere!  We can ship to any country in the world. Shipping internationally from Japan can be a little expensive but we've done our best to keep it as low as possible. Shipping prices are included in reward descriptions and must be added on the next page.  All shipping is express and includes tracking and insurance.
What does "Gekka" mean? - Gekka (月下) literally translates to "under the moon" from Japanese.  We used this as inspiration for our name, logo, and story.
How do I choose which items and sizes I want? - After the campaign is over, we will be sending you a link to a page where you can choose the ones you want!
Are Japanese sizes different? - Japanese sizes tend to be a bit smaller than Western sizes.  When choosing your items, it is a good idea to choose one size larger than you would usually in Western countries.
Can you use chopsticks? - YES!
We are so excited and grateful that you took the time to look at our campaign page. If you believe in what we are trying to do, please share it with your friends in any way that you can to help us make this dream a reality!  Don't forget to follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for more updates in the future.  One last thing... Smile big!
日本語訳はこちら！

story:
Brokenhead is a British psychological thriller feature film by award winning writer and director Steve Rainbow. Set on the isolated peninsular of Spurn Head on the Yorkshire coast, Brokenhead will be one of the most stunning looking and atmospheric films of the decade and Steve wants to give you the opportunity to be a producer on this film. 

Steve's years of experience and vast network in films has enabled him to secure 90% of the films budget leaving just 10% left to raise before filming can start. 

This is where you come in. Take a look at the PERKS on the right and if you see one you fancy go for it!

And remember this…your money may come and go but BROKENHEAD will be here for ever. 

Outline
Sven is the last lighthouse keeper in the world. He has turned his back on society and lives the idyllic life of a hermit, answerable to no one and he does as he pleases all day long. His only responsibility is to keep the light burning, but his time alone is running out and just like a moth to the flame his past is drawing nearer and nearer until one night it knocks on his lighthouse door. 

Steve Rainbow - Writer & Director
Steve's first feature film was selected for the prestigious Edinburgh International Film Festival, receiving rave reviews from Screen International and The Guardian and in 2013 secured UK and European distribution. His second feature film completed this year has already screened at three international film festivals and his most recent film was nominated for a Royal Television Society Award. In 15 years of film making Steve has won several awards and created films that have graced the screens of the very highest of international film festivals and he continues to push his unique style of observational films to wide global audiences.
In 2013 Steve started The Birmingham Film Company with his business partner and Producer Blair Kesseler. Blair has over 40 years experience of fund management.

Steve's previous films can be seen at www.rainbowfilms.co.uk

Sean Connolly - Lead ActorIn a long career, Sean has appeared in a variety of content on TV and film and recently voiced several characters in the block buster Shaun the Sheep – The Movie. In terms of global recognition Sean is the voice of Davros' father in the Audio World of Doctor Who. (For those of you who don't know Davros, he created the Daleks) so this film has a main-line right into classic British horror genre before it's even been shot and also guarantees a huge following of interest.  Sean is one of the most respected voice over actors in the UK and for this reason was selected to play the lead character, who when not looking after the lighthouse, turns a trick as a voice over actor for commercials and radio plays. It is one of these commissions that brings the story of Brokenhead to its terrifying climax. http://www.seanconnolly.co.uk

Andy Garbi - Composer
Andy is an internationally recognised composer and his album The Sound of One reach No. 1 in the Ambient Album Chart. The recurring theme track for this film called Mirrors can be heard on his website http://www.andygarbi.com/audio-tracks/363/

We need £15,000 to finish the film and promote its distribution-and you can help

£50 - Your name on the film
£150 - Your name & company logo on the film
£500 - Co Producer credit + 0.5% producers net profits
£1000 - Executive Producer credit + 1.25% producers net profits

Live the dream and become a film producer and help make a brilliant classic British thriller. 

The money needed is for props, travel, food for the cast and crew and specific lighting equipment needed for shooting in a lighthouse. All other costs are covered.

The £50 perk is a treat and well worth it.
The £150 perk is great business sense.
The £500 and £1000 perks are great opportunities to make money and open up a whole new world of business.

Your money may come and go but BROKENHEAD will be here forever!


Charity

The film is being shot on location at the stunning Sprun Head Point in Yorkshire and  small percentage of the profits will go to the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust to help with the upkeep of this amazing, unique and haunting part of the British coats line.

In keeping with Steve's beliefs of inclusion and the promotion of creativity, the production of the film is giving the opportunity of on the job experience to students studying film from the Birmingham area.

story:
Put yourself in the seat with us as we document the Ukrainian war in Donbass. I was the first western journalist writing about Ukraine from Donbass and the only one that has been here the entire time. I live here.

Over the past year, the one thing that has been made clear is the lack of unbiased western journalism and news coverage in Donbass covering the war. Kiev admits to propagandizing everything it releases to western media.

 There have been no efforts to getting dedicated English language news video directly to western news and media from inside the LNR and DNR on a continual basis. Most efforts are geared for Russian speaking audiences first with English versions following as an afterthought.

Together we can change that!

Endorsements from Leading Publications and Journalists

 Globalresearch.ca GR Edtor’s Note"We call upon GR Readers to support independent media in Donbass by making a contribution a documentary team located in the war zone. Global Research has made an initial contribution to this important endeavor."

Robert Kall OpEdNews.com

This is essential work, casting clear light of truth on a story primarily being narrated by neoliberal warhawks who wouldn’t know the truth if they accidentally stumbled into it. It takes great courage to report from a war zone. That’s why I’ve made a donation to support this valuable work. Please join me in helping reach the goal of this funding project.

Washingtonsblog- Crowdfund a Videocam So We Can See What’s REALLY Going On

Intrepid American reporter George Eliason is living in – and reporting from – Ukraine.

He’s risking his life to bring us unbiased, on-the-ground reporting in English … which we can’t get anywhere else.

Mick Meaney(RINF) – George Eliason was the first western journalist to write unbiased reports about the ongoing events in Ukraine, and now he needs our help. George is in desperate need of a camera to help him document the facts that counter the onslaught of propaganda from governments and the corporate media.

This is the exact reason RINF exists – to support independent journalism, and the reason that you continue to visit the site. Please take a look at his indiegogo appeal and contribute whatever you can – it is only with your help can independent journalists continue to report the truth

.The VineyardSaker

I encourage everybody do donate as much as you can to help George Eliason work *for us all* in the Ukraine!The Saker

Russia-Insider-We’ve worked a lot with George over the past year, and can recommend him wholeheartedly. 

He’s risking his life to get the truth out.  It doesn’t get much more real, or more admirable, than that. We were never able to pay him, and he never asked, just did what he thought was right.  Now we have a chance to help him. If you can, please share on social media - it really helps...This is how alternative media happens - regular folks, giving a few bucks at a time, or volunteering a few hours. 

Here at Russia Insider, we understand that very well.  So let’s keep up the pressure  We are making a difference.. - Charles Bausman

 “The best journalism on the war in Ukraine are the articles by the American who lives there, George Eliason."-Eric Zuesse: Journalist, Investigative historian and author, most recently, of They’re Not Even Close: The Democratic vs. Republican Economic Records, 1910-2010, and of CHRIST’S VENTRILOQUISTS: The Event that Created Christianity

Michael Collins- is a featured contributor to OpEdNews, one of top 100 political web sites on the internet.  Collins is a Washington DC area writer, researcher, and citizen journalist. His home page is http://opednews.com/michaelcollins

"George Eliason’s reporting from Ukraine offers a first hand account of events from the epicenter of the conflict.Time after time, George was the first to break major stories on the battle for Novorussia and key elements of the resistance to the Kiev junta’s fascist forces.In addition, George’s background research and analysis help us understand the pervasive influence of Bandera movement.The current effort to expand reporting through additional resources has all the elements of success."

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding for a news quality camera and accessories. With the camera, we will be able to bring substantial English language documentary video to the west and put you right there with us. 

Our goal is to bring video footage to good news and alternative media websites that otherwise would not have access to video, documentaries, and commentary from Donbas in English direct to them- Free of Charge.

 For the past year that's where most of our own income has been going and we are not going to change that. We plan to continue helping the humanitarian effort in Donbass and expand on it by selling some of the news footage to news agencies. That will help fund the humanitarian effort locally on a continuous basis.

 We have been fortunate enough to be involved in humanitarian aid and distributing medication locally. We are also painfully aware of what happens when aid doesn't get to where it is needed. Together we can help change this for the better.

For the camera and the needed accessories, we will need $4500. This will cover all the transfer fees and give a complete news camera set up that is ready to go. We don't need the top of the line options but do require a camera with a lot of versatility to gain war footage and do interviews that has high resolution and is still unobtrusive.

Funding beyond that will go into the humanitarian effort and help fund documentary work directly in between news events. Documentary work by itself is an expensive endeavor if just transportation costs are added in. We will take you directly to the places that are being affected hardest by the war and let people speak for themselves.

The Impact your Funding will Make

Your funding will make a large impact in western media by making quality video footage continuously available to websites you know and trust. Currently its the lack of direct English language news coverage from the war that is the biggest news about it in the west. If a picture is worth a thousand words how much are direct footage and witnesses from the scene worth when the alternative is Ukrainian propaganda?

With your funding it will become very hard to keep the real facts out of mainstream media because they will have to start looking at English language video from someone that has lived and reported from here the entire time. We will be providing quality news websites with interviews and asking their involvement on select interviews as we go. In many cases, this will mean the journalists you currently read will have input on the questions asked to the people shaping both the war and beginning of Novorussia.

Can we make an impact across the world together? The answer is yes, we can!

The Bakery Project

At the beginning of the Ukrainian war, Kiev started to blockade even critical medications like insulin and heart medications. When the fighting started it became a common practice for them to mine the grain fields across Donbass. By mid-summer, this happened in such a widespread pattern that it was easy to forecast a food shortage in Donbass through the winter and increasing until the next harvest happens. The fields had to be demined and thousands of acres remain unplanted today.

Nearby our location is a bread bakery that has been sitting idle for 2 years. The bakery is capable of providing bread for thousands of people continually if opened up again. Our plan to sell video footage to news agencies for resale originated in starting a self -sustaining humanitarian effort supported by news video footage sales. 

This way the project may become self sustaining and help build the local economy by purchasing grain locally from farmers in need of cash, using the local grain mill, and hiring local people to work in the bakery itself. We will be able to provide a continuous  supply of bread where it is needed.

This is ultimately what your generosity is funding. Contrary to the Minsk Agreements Kiev is still blockading food and medication from entering Donbass. The aid Russia is giving will never be enough. 

Together we can make a difference.


About Us


For the past year, I have been writing breaking news and background articles about the events in Ukraine and Donbass including the earliest articles about the Ukrainian Nationalist coup in Kiev. I've provided a lot of background articles so journalists could get their heads around what was really happening here.

When Kiev started mobilizing tanks and soldiers to Donbas I wrote the first articles to appear in the west. Starting with a mid-February article detailing why the war was coming and genocide with it I wrote about the importance of understanding the Ukrainian political program and how the Banderavites could not change.

 I broke the news about the beginning of the war from the Good Friday attacks in Odessa through the Easter attacks in Slavyansk. We spoke to people on the ground throughout the region the whole time getting their real opinions out during the build-up to the referendum on May 11th and afterward.

I wrote the first detailed articles about the Odessa massacre to appear in the west and follow-ups as Kiev's complicity came into focus through evidence.

After that time we were able to provide first hand coverage of what it was like to be in an area under attack and then under the control of Pravy Sektor, the Natz Guardia, Donbass Battalion, etc. We gave first hand accounts of what it was like to be in a zone that was slated to be cleansed and only got a reprieve when the battle that turned the tide of the Ukrainian war happened literally one bus stop away from us.

When I've written about any Russian invasion never happening it's because the great “stealth invasion” of August 2014 would have knocked over the tomato plants in my garden to happen at all. In articles from that battle site, I took photos clearly showing how close the Russian border was to the site and noted my own location was directly in line of sight to it. In other words the invasion didin't happen.

I was the first western journalist to do invasive passport checks on soldiers in Donbass documenting where they were from. I believe I am the only western journalist to do weapons checks for fabrication dates. These both provide the necessary proofs against a Russian invasion and modern Russian weapons in Donbass.

During this time, my wife has become very involved and helps in research and documentation. Together we'll be making the documentaries. Together we will do the interviews. Making the humanitarian effort succeed is personal to her. She grew up in Donbass and we have many relatives and friends here.

Risks & Challenges

It's a war zone. The risks are real. The death and destruction are real and so are the crimes against humanity being perpetrated here. The challenges are multifold. Interviewing people and trying to protect their dignity or demand for privacy is paramount. We won't victimize our neighbors further any more than you would your own under these circumstances. Getting the truth out will happen but it can be done respectfully with people that have been hurt in this war already.

I think that is another point that separates us from other efforts. We were here before all of this started and we'll be here after it all ends. 

Maintaining our own safety while collecting the documentary stories, war footage, and interviews takes planning and coordination. We already have that support structure in place as well as field helmets and vests. Part of the coordination effort is to know where the front line is at all times so you don't get caught on the wrong side which is bad, or in between which is worse.

We are planning on documenting the humanitarian aid effort that will stem from this effort after it gets going. Ultimately that is the larger goal for us. We feel that by providing the video proof of delivery on that end and with a little help we can build a close to self sustaining effort quickly. Initially we wanted to do this as a private effort. The situation made that impossible.

With only the camera in hand it will take a little time but we will be able to make a difference on that end. Our goal is to reopen a local bread bakery and bake humanitarian loaves. This was the initial reason behind the fund raising effort.

How fast this part starts is directly dependent on whether or not our initial goal is reached to purchase the camera and how far beyond that donations will go. If we fall short we will work with what we have to start with. This is too important not to get started.

If we go past our goal the total of the funds will determine how they will be allocated. If there is enough to reopen the bakery then we can get started with that project directly. If there is more then we can put more money directly into purchase of medications.

If there is extra funding but not enough to start this effort we will put funds into other existing local aid we are working with. This way the aid reaches the people it needs to.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help but can't contribute please ask people you know to get the word out. Use the idiegogo share tools. The more people that help the lighter the load will be. Help by putting this throughout your social media.

Remember the closer we get to the goal the harder it is to reach. People get complacent when the finish line's real close and it looks like we' ll finish the race a winner. Please remind your friends as the campaign winds down to consider donating.

We need funding for a news quality camera and accessories. With the camera, we will be able to bring substantial English language documentary video to the west and put you right there with us. 

Our goal is to bring video footage to good news and alternative media websites that otherwise would not have access to video, documentaries, and commentary from Donbas in English direct to them- Free of Charge.
 For the past year that's where most of our own income has been going and we are not going to change that. We plan to continue helping the humanitarian effort in Donbass and expand on it by selling some of the news footage to news agencies. That will help fund the humanitarian effort locally on a continuous basis.
 We have been fortunate enough to be involved in humanitarian aid and distributing medication locally. We are also painfully aware of what happens when aid doesn't get to where it is needed. Together we can help change this for the better.

For the camera and the needed accessories, we will need $4500. This will cover all the transfer fees and give a complete news camera set up that is ready to go. We don't need the top of the line options but do require a camera with a lot of versatility to gain war footage and do interviews that has high resolution and is still unobtrusive.
Funding beyond that will go into the humanitarian effort and help fund documentary work directly in between news events. Documentary work by itself is an expensive endeavor if just transportation costs are added in. We will take you directly to the places that are being affected hardest by the war and let people speak for themselves.

The Impact your Funding will Make
Your funding will make a large impact in western media by making quality video footage continuously available to websites you know and trust. Currently its the lack of direct English language news coverage from the war that is the biggest news about it in the west. If a picture is worth a thousand words how much are direct footage and witnesses from the scene worth when the alternative is Ukrainian propaganda?

With your funding it will become very hard to keep the real facts out of mainstream media because they will have to start looking at English language video from someone that has lived and reported from here the entire time. We will be providing quality news websites with interviews and asking their involvement on select interviews as we go. In many cases, this will mean the journalists you currently read will have input on the questions asked to the people shaping both the war and beginning of Novorussia.
Can we make an impact across the world together? The answer is yes, we can!

The Bakery Project
At the beginning of the Ukrainian war, Kiev started to blockade even critical medications like insulin and heart medications. When the fighting started it became a common practice for them to mine the grain fields across Donbass. By mid-summer, this happened in such a widespread pattern that it was easy to forecast a food shortage in Donbass through the winter and increasing until the next harvest happens. The fields had to be demined and thousands of acres remain unplanted today.
Nearby our location is a bread bakery that has been sitting idle for 2 years. The bakery is capable of providing bread for thousands of people continually if opened up again. Our plan to sell video footage to news agencies for resale originated in starting a self -sustaining humanitarian effort supported by news video footage sales. This way the project may become self sustaining and help build the local economy by purchasing grain locally from farmers in need of cash, using the local grain mill, and hiring local people to work in the bakery itself. We will be able to provide a continuous  supply of bread where it is needed.
This is ultimately what your generosity is funding. Contrary to the Minsk Agreements Kiev is still blockading food and medication from entering Donbass. The aid Russia is giving will never be enough. 
Together we can make a difference.

About Us

For the past year, I have been writing breaking news and background articles about the events in Ukraine and Donbass including the earliest articles about the Ukrainian Nationalist coup in Kiev. I've provided a lot of background articles so journalists could get their heads around what was really happening here.
When Kiev started mobilizing tanks and soldiers to Donbas I wrote the first articles to appear in the west. Starting with a mid-February article detailing why the war was coming and genocide with it I wrote about the importance of understanding the Ukrainian political program and how the Banderavites could not change. I broke the news about the beginning of the war from the Good Friday attacks in Odessa through the Easter attacks in Slavyansk. We spoke to people on the ground throughout the region the whole time getting their real opinions out during the build-up to the referendum on May 11th and afterward.

I wrote the first detailed articles about the Odessa massacre to appear in the west and follow-ups as Kiev's complicity came into focus through evidence.
After that time we were able to provide first hand coverage of what it was like to be in an area under attack and then under the control of Pravy Sektor, the Natz Guardia, Donbass Battalion, etc. We gave first hand accounts of what it was like to be in a zone that was slated to be cleansed and only got a reprieve when the battle that turned the tide of the Ukrainian war happened literally one bus stop away from us.
When I've written about any Russian invasion never happening it's because the great “stealth invasion” of August 2014 would have knocked over the tomato plants in my garden to happen at all. In articles from that battle site, I took photos clearly showing how close the Russian border was to the site and noted my own location was directly in line of sight to it. In other words the invasion didin't happen.

I was the first western journalist to do invasive passport checks on soldiers in Donbass documenting where they were from. I believe I am the only western journalist to do weapons checks for fabrication dates. These both provide the necessary proofs against a Russian invasion and modern Russian weapons in Donbass.
During this time, my wife has become very involved and helps in research and documentation. Together we'll be making the documentaries. Together we will do the interviews. Making the humanitarian effort succeed is personal to her. She grew up in Donbass and we have many relatives and friends here.
Risks & Challenges
It's a war zone. The risks are real. The death and destruction are real and so are the crimes against humanity being perpetrated here. The challenges are multifold. Interviewing people and trying to protect their dignity or demand for privacy is paramount. We won't victimize our neighbors further any more than you would your own under these circumstances. Getting the truth out will happen but it can be done respectfully with people that have been hurt in this war already.
I think that is another point that separates us from other efforts. We were here before all of this started and we'll be here after it all ends. 
Maintaining our own safety while collecting the documentary stories, war footage, and interviews takes planning and coordination. We already have that support structure in place as well as field helmets and vests. Part of the coordination effort is to know where the front line is at all times so you don't get caught on the wrong side which is bad, or in between which is worse.
We are planning on documenting the humanitarian aid effort that will stem from this effort after it gets going. Ultimately that is the larger goal for us. We feel that by providing the video proof of delivery on that end and with a little help we can build a close to self sustaining effort quickly. Initially we wanted to do this as a private effort. The situation made that impossible.
With only the camera in hand it will take a little time but we will be able to make a difference on that end. Our goal is to reopen a local bread bakery and bake humanitarian loaves. This was the initial reason behind the fund raising effort.

How fast this part starts is directly dependent on whether or not our initial goal is reached to purchase the camera and how far beyond that donations will go. If we fall short we will work with what we have to start with. This is too important not to get started.
If we go past our goal the total of the funds will determine how they will be allocated. If there is enough to reopen the bakery then we can get started with that project directly. If there is more then we can put more money directly into purchase of medications.
If there is extra funding but not enough to start this effort we will put funds into other existing local aid we are working with. This way the aid reaches the people it needs to.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you want to help but can't contribute please ask people you know to get the word out. Use the idiegogo share tools. The more people that help the lighter the load will be. Help by putting this throughout your social media.
Remember the closer we get to the goal the harder it is to reach. People get complacent when the finish line's real close and it looks like we' ll finish the race a winner. Please remind your friends as the campaign winds down to consider donating.

story:
Just Eat  is a documentary that follows the deadliest, least funded, and most ignored mental illness in America. Eating disorders wreak havoc on millions of Americans every year, yet the misconceptions of the disease continue to hinder research progress, treatment access, and keep medical professionals uninformed.

The film enters the world of two individuals fighting a war in their minds and bodies. Through the personal stories of those living with their disease, we learn of the hope that treatment provides, as well as the difficulty in obtaining proper care.

Deconstructing the myths around eating disorders helps bring reality closer. 

The truth is eating disorders affect both men and women. For females of African-American, Asian-American, Hispanic, and White descent, the overall prevalence of eating disorders is equal. Taking the focus off stereotypes and turning it towards the facts will create the awareness necessary to tackle this epidemic.

Anorexics are likely to die at a rate of 18x their peers if they are diagnosed in their 20’s, making it by far the most deadly mental illness. Over 4% of all Americans will have an eating disorder in their lifetime. 

We know that this is a high rate of incidence, yet why in 2011 did the National Institute of Health spend $84 per afflicted individual with schizophrenia compared with only $0.93 per afflicted with eating disorders?

Just Eat will face the facts and ask the questions: Why is the deadliest mental illness the least funded and the most ignored?

This film started four years ago, approximately three days after I mustered up the courage to Google “anorexia” for the first time. I had been diagnosed with the illness four years prior, but the name alone carried with it the secrecy and fear that clouded my ability to see the societal significance of my story. I had no idea I was one of millions. Or that getting proper help is hard for nearly everyone with an eating disorder. Or that there are people actively trying to change all of that at the federal level, driven by their own brushes with death or loss of loved ones.

The fear turned into a responsibility I couldn’t walk away from as the magnitude of this story unfolded. Why was no one talking about this?

I no longer viewed my experience with anorexia as a traumatizing experience from my past, but as a filmmaker with an important story to tell.

By replacing the ill-informed idea that eating disorders exist solely on the covers of fashion magazines with the pressing issues of insurance denials and federal oversight, the way we talk about them will change. No other film has done this.

My story is no longer about me. It is merely one of countless instances demanding representation.

Just Eat  illuminates a story untold. Pioneers in the field of eating disorder research tell us what the science says, including the link between brain and behavior using genetics and brain imaging. One of the few lawyers in the country who exclusively takes on eating disorder cases tells us of the battle against the insurance companies that deny treatment coverage. The Director of the National Institute for Mental Health and members of Congress discuss how eating disorders rank on a federal level, while we see hundreds of individuals from across the country lobby on Capitol Hill every six months for a change in policy.

Our notable panel of experts tell us why the story is important, but the main characters of this film are the ones living  this story. This is what we still need to film. The audience will enter the mind of someone fighting their disease, while following their external fight for treatment, support, and recognition in spite of stereotypes. 


This film has been entirely independently funded up to this point. A wealth of talented, generous, and passionate friends have made this film what it is right now, but in order to resume filming at the standard of quality it needs we need your support.

Your money will help take us through the last few months of shooting. Travel expenses, gear rentals, talented people to operate that gear, not to mention random necessities like batteries, hard drives, fanny packs, etc.

Here’s how our costs break down:


You, my friends, get some seriously cool stuff for donating. Check out just a few of our featured perks below.
Not pictured: The satisfaction that comes from donating and our deep gratitude.

There has been no other film that addresses eating disorders in this way. We all have a chance at contributing to something pretty great: A new conversation about eating disorders and about those who have them.

Being honest, open, and pragmatic about them lessens the power they have over those they control, and puts an end to the hushed stigmatization that prevents people from getting the life-saving help they need.

That’s what this film will do. It opens the door for new discourse. It opens the door for change. We invite you to be a part of that.

Once the film is [gasp!] completed, we will take this conversation to the public by entering it into various film festivals and a coordinated tour of US college campuses.

We really believe this is just the beginning.

Laura has worked in the journalism and film production world for over six years. She brings a firm commitment to journalistic integrity and as much objectivity is allowed of her. She served as co-producer and lead writer on the feature documentary Out of Respect in 2009, has since gone on to work for Al Jazeera English, Discovery, NBC, and National Geographic, and is a producer of The Myken Project documentary, currently in production. This is her first feature film.


Documentaries are unpredictable by nature. You often cannot control the circumstances any better than you can control the lives you are documenting.

Realistic challenges include the likelihood of needing more funding later in the production process. This campaign will without doubt kickstart us into our final filming phase, which will take us one step closer to the film’s completion.

One primary challenge we are facing is the subject nature itself. The individuals we are following, currently battling their eating disorder, will have a support system in place during the filming process. We will be keenly cautious of any negative effect the camera may have on their well-being, while at the same time prepare ourselves to show the rawness of their mental state.

One thing we are certain of: The film will be completed. No matter what.

We are prepared to raise the additional funds necessary once we enter the post-production and distribution phases, and will be sure to keep our backers updated every step of the way.


We completely understand that making a monetary donation may not be an option for some people. THAT'S OKAY. You can very much still be a part of this process and support Just Eat by sharing it to anyone and everyone who will listen. 

Facebook. Twitter. Tumblr. Tinder (maybe?). Google+. The water cooler. 

In fact, IndieGoGo makes this very easy with their share tools!


If you or someone you know is struggling with an eating disorder, here are a list of very helpful websites:

National Eating Disorders Association (www.nationaleatingdisorders.org)

Men Get EDs Too (www.mengetedstoo.co.uk)

Binge Eating Disorder Association (www.bingeeatingdisorder.com)

NEDA Helpline:  800-931-2237

story: Tauhir Theys was born and lives in Woodstock, Cape Town. He was selected for the South African mixed team for the Touch Rugby World Cup in Coffs Harbour Australia. The world cup is self funding and each player must raise his own funds. Tauhir is 20 years of age and is one of South Africa's most talented upcoming players. He needs your support! Please donate and select a perk where you will stand a chance of winning some great prizes!

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everybody, my name is David Raibon.  I've been a comedian, writer and actor for over 20 years. The one-eyed gentleman in the photo in burgundy and stocking cap is my character "Van Bro" from FX's "The Shield" (On dvd). I've also been on many comedy stages including The Apollo Theater in Harlem, Martin Lawrence's 1st Amendment, HBO Def Comedy Jam,  BET's Comic View, comedy tours in Iraq to tours around the world. I've lived the life of a comedian. It's not always as funny as it appears to be. For most of us it is therapy! For the audience most of the time it's just hilarious!

After looking into the life and death of comedians like Robin Harris and more recently Robin Williams who were both tremendously funny but had dark sides to them. The idea hit me why not create a Real reality show about comedians. Explore the painful origin that fuels the funny when a comedian tells an abrasive joke that makes everybody fall on the floor laughing? I imagined if I could have captured some live candid footage of the legendary Richard Pryor, how cool would that have been. Unfortunately, that won't happen but I did get to meet him and shake his hand behind The Comedy Store years ago. A dream come true.

I want to take you into the lives of (5) accomplished and perhaps not as accomplished but hilarious comedians with deep stories to tell. I feel that telling these stories will open up the public's eye as to the sacrifices made by the folks blessed and cursed with a sense of humor. Too often comedians are mostly  appreciated after they have passed. RIP, Bernie Mack!

The most important medicine given to mankind is laughter. It makes the heart stronger. Comedy helps curtail depression and anger as well, if not just temporarily. Help me bring to television in a reality show format, a series that will explore the depths of comedy and the comedians entrusted with making us laugh out loud!

I appreciate you spreading the word so this campaign will end quickly and successfully and casting can begin. Again, I'm David and I appreciate your donations! Let's show the world who truly are "The Real Funny of LA!" 

The Future: The Real Funny of ...Houston, Atlanta, Miami and New York City!!
